12660	16	12	35	 and certain of the priests' sons with trumpets: Zechariah the son of Jonathan, the son of Shemaiah, the son of Mattaniah, the son of Micaiah, the son of Zaccur, the son of Asaph;
12661	16	12	36	 and his brethren, Shemaiah, and Azarel, Milalai, Gilalai, Maai, Nethanel, and Judah, Hanani, with the musical instruments of David the man of God; and Ezra the scribe was before them;
12662	16	12	37	 and by the fountain gate, and straight before them, they went up by the stairs of the city of David, at the going up of the wall, above the house of David, even unto the water gate eastward.
12663	16	12	38	 And the other company of them that gave thanks went to meet them, and I after them, with the half of the people, upon the wall, above the tower of the furnaces, even unto the broad wall;
12664	16	12	39	 and above the gate of Ephraim, and by the gate of the old city and by the fish gate, and the tower of Hananel, and the tower of Hammeah, even unto the sheep gate; and they stood still in the gate of the guard.
12665	16	12	40	 So stood the two companies of them that gave thanks in the house of God, and I, and the half of the rulers with me;
12666	16	12	41	 and the priests, Eliakim, Maaseiah, Miniamin, Micaiah, Elioenai, Zechariah, and Hananiah, with trumpets;
12667	16	12	42	 and Maaseiah, and Shemaiah, and Eleazar, and Uzzi, and Jehohanan, and Malchijah, and Elam, and Ezer. And the singers sang loud, with Jezrahiah their overseer.
12668	16	12	43	 And they offered great sacrifices that day, and rejoiced; for God had made them rejoice with great joy; and the women also and the children rejoiced; so that the joy of Jerusalem was heard even afar off.
12669	16	12	44	 And on that day were men appointed over the chambers for the treasures, for the heave-offerings, for the first-fruits, and for the tithes, to gather into them, according to the fields of the cities, the portions appointed by the law for the priests and Levites; for Judah rejoiced for the priests and for the Levites that took their stations.
12670	16	12	45	 And they kept the ward of their God, and the ward of the purification, and so did the singers and the porters, according to the commandment of David, and of Solomon his son.
12671	16	12	46	 For in the days of David and Asaph of old there were chief of the singers, and songs of praise and thanksgiving unto God.
12672	16	12	47	 And all Israel in the days of Zerubbabel, and in the days of Nehemiah, gave the portions of the singers and the porters, as every day required; and they hallowed for the Levites; and the Levites hallowed for the sons of Aaron.
12673	16	13	1	 On that day they read in the book of Moses in the hearing of the people; and therein was found written, that an Ammonite and a Moabite should not enter into the assembly of God for ever;
12674	16	13	2	 because they met not the children of Israel with bread and with water, but hired Balaam against them, to curse them; howbeit our God turned the curse into a blessing.
12675	16	13	3	 And it came to pass, when they had heard the law, that they separated from Israel all the alien mixture.
12676	16	13	4	 Now before this, Eliashib the priest, who was appointed over the chambers of the house of our God, being allied unto Tobiah,
12677	16	13	5	 had prepared for him a great chamber, where aforetime they laid the meal-offerings, the frankincense, and the vessels, and the tithes of the corn, the wine, and the oil, which were given by commandment to the Levites, and the singers, and the porters; and the heave-offerings for the priests.
12678	16	13	6	 But in all this time I was not at Jerusalem; for in the two and thirtieth year of Artaxerxes king of Babylon I went unto the king, and after certain days asked I leave of the king;
12679	16	13	7	 and I came to Jerusalem, and understood the evil that Eliashib had done for Tobiah, in preparing him a chamber in the courts of the house of God.
12680	16	13	8	 And it grieved me sore; therefore I cast forth all the household stuff of Tobiah out of the chamber.
12681	16	13	9	 Then I commanded, and they cleansed the chambers; and thither brought I again the vessels of the house of God, with the meal-offerings and the frankincense.
12682	16	13	10	 And I perceived that the portions of the Levites had not been given them; so that the Levites and the singers, that did the work, were fled every one to his field.
12683	16	13	11	 Then contended I with the rulers, and said: 'Why is the house of God forsaken?' And I gathered them together, and set them in their place.
12684	16	13	12	 Then brought all Judah the tithe of the corn and the wine and the oil unto the treasuries.
12685	16	13	13	 And I made treasurers over the treasuries, Shelemiah the priest, and Zadok the scribe, and of the Levites, Pedaiah; and next to them was Hanan the son of Zaccur, the son of Mattaniah; for they were counted faithful, and their office was to distribute unto their brethren.
12686	16	13	14	 Remember me, O my God, concerning this, and wipe not out my good deeds that I have done for the house of my God, and for the wards thereof.
12687	16	13	15	 In those days saw I in Judah some treading winepresses on the sabbath, and bringing in heaps of corn, and lading asses therewith; as also wine, grapes, and figs, and all manner of burdens, which they brought into Jerusalem on the sabbath day; and I forewarned them in the day wherein they sold victuals.
12688	16	13	16	 There dwelt men of Tyre also therein, who brought in fish, and all manner of ware, and sold on the sabbath unto the children of Judah, and in Jerusalem.
12689	16	13	17	 Then I contended with the nobles of Judah, and said unto them: 'What evil thing is this that ye do, and profane the sabbath day?
12690	16	13	18	 Did not your fathers thus, and did not our God bring all this evil upon us, and upon this city? yet ye bring more wrath upon Israel by profaning the sabbath.'
12691	16	13	19	 And it came to pass that, when the gates of Jerusalem began to be dark before the sabbath, I commanded that the doors should be shut, and commanded that they should not be opened till after the sabbath; and some of my servants set I over the gates, that there should no burden be brought in on the sabbath day.
12692	16	13	20	 So the merchants and sellers of all kind of ware lodged without Jerusalem once or twice.
12693	16	13	21	 Then I forewarned them, and said unto them: 'Why lodge ye about the wall? if ye do so again, I will lay hands on you.' From that time forth came they no more on the sabbath.
12694	16	13	22	 And I commanded the Levites that they should purify themselves, and that they should come and keep the gates, to sanctify the sabbath day. Remember unto me, O my God, this also, and spare me according to the greatness of Thy mercy.
12695	16	13	23	 In those days also saw I the Jews that had married women of Ashdod, of Ammon, and of Moab;
12696	16	13	24	 and their children spoke half in the speech of Ashdod, and could not speak in the Jews' language, but according to the language of each people.
12697	16	13	25	 And I contended with them, and cursed them, and smote certain of them, and plucked off their hair, and made them swear by God: 'Ye shall not give your daughters unto their sons, nor take their daughters for your sons, or for yourselves.
12698	16	13	26	 Did not Solomon king of Israel sin by these things? yet among many nations was there no king like him, and he was beloved of his God, and God made him king over all Israel; nevertheless even him did the foreign women cause to sin.
12699	16	13	27	 Shall we then hearken unto you to do all this great evil, to break faith with our God in marrying foreign women?'
12700	16	13	28	 And one of the sons of Joiada, the son of Eliashib the high priest, was son-in-law to Sanballat the Horonite; therefore I chased him from me.
12701	16	13	29	 Remember them, O my God, because they have defiled the priesthood, and the covenant of the priesthood, and of the Levites.
12702	16	13	30	 Thus cleansed I them from everything foreign, and appointed wards for the priests and for the Levites, every one in his work;
12703	16	13	31	 and for the wood-offering, at times appointed, and for the first-fruits. Remember me, O my God, for good.
12704	17	1	1	 NOW IT came to pass in the days of Ahasuerus--this is Ahasuerus who reigned, from India even unto Ethiopia, over a hundred and seven and twenty provinces--
12705	17	1	2	 that in those days, when the king Ahasuerus sat on the throne of his kingdom, which was in Shushan the castle,
12706	17	1	3	 in the third year of his reign, he made a feast unto all his princes and his servants; the army of Persia and Media, the nobles and princes of the provinces, being before him;
12707	17	1	4	 when he showed the riches of his glorious kingdom and the honour of his excellent majesty, many days, even a hundred and fourscore days.
12708	17	1	5	 And when these days were fulfilled, the king made a feast unto all the people that were present in Shushan the castle, both great and small, seven days, in the court of the garden of the king's palace;
12709	17	1	6	 there were hangings of white, fine cotton, and blue, bordered with cords of fine linen and purple, upon silver rods and pillars of marble; the couches were of gold and silver, upon a pavement of green, and white, and shell, and onyx marble.
12710	17	1	7	 And they gave them drink in vessels of gold--the vessels being diverse one from another--and royal wine in abundance, according to the bounty of the king.
12711	17	1	8	 And the drinking was according to the law; none did compel; for so the king had appointed to all the officers of his house, that they should do according to every man's pleasure.
12712	17	1	9	 Also Vashti the queen made a feast for the women in the royal house which belonged to king Ahasuerus.
12713	17	1	10	 On the seventh day, when the heart of the king was merry with wine, he commanded Mehuman, Bizzetha, Harbona, Bigtha, and Abagtha, Zethar, and Carcas, the seven chamberlains that ministered in the presence of Ahasuerus the king,
12714	17	1	11	 to bring Vashti the queen before the king with the crown royal, to show the peoples and the princes her beauty; for she was fair to look on.
12715	17	1	12	 But the queen Vashti refused to come at the king's commandment by the chamberlains; therefore was the king very wroth, and his anger burned in him.
12716	17	1	13	 Then the king said to the wise men, who knew the times--for so was the king's manner toward all that knew law and judgment;
12717	17	1	14	 and the next unto him was Carshena, Shethar, Admatha, Tarshish, Meres, Marsena, and Memucan, the seven princes of Persia and Media, who saw the king's face, and sat the first in the kingdom:
12718	17	1	15	 'What shall we do unto the queen Vashti according to law, forasmuch as she hath not done the bidding of the king Ahasuerus by the chamberlains?'
12719	17	1	16	 And Memucan answered before the king and the princes: 'Vashti the queen hath not done wrong to the king only, but also to all the princes, and to all the peoples, that are in all the provinces of the king Ahasuerus.
12720	17	1	17	 For this deed of the queen will come abroad unto all women, to make their husbands contemptible in their eyes, when it will be said: The king Ahasuerus commanded Vashti the queen to be brought in before him, but she came not.
12721	17	1	18	 And this day will the princesses of Persia and Media who have heard of the deed of the queen say the like unto all the king's princes. So will there arise enough contempt and wrath.
12722	17	1	19	 If it please the king, let there go forth a royal commandment from him, and let it be written among the laws of the Persians and the Medes, that it be not altered, that Vashti come no more before king Ahasuerus, and that the king give her royal estate unto another that is better than she.
12723	17	1	20	 And when the king's decree which he shall make shall be published throughout all his kingdom, great though it be, all the wives will give to their husbands honour, both to great and small.'
12724	17	1	21	 And the word pleased the king and the princes; and the king did according to the word of Memucan;
12725	17	1	22	 for he sent letters into all the king's provinces, into every province according to the writing thereof, and to every people after their language, that every man should bear rule in his own house, and speak according to the language of his people.
12726	17	2	1	 After these things, when the wrath of king Ahasuerus was assuaged, he remembered Vashti, and what she had done, and what was decreed against her.
12727	17	2	2	 Then said the king's servants that ministered unto him: 'Let there be sought for the king young virgins fair to look on;
12728	17	2	3	 and let the king appoint officers in all the provinces of his kingdom, that they may gather together all the fair young virgins unto Shushan the castle, to the house of the women, unto the custody of Hegai the king's chamberlain, keeper of the women; and let their ointments be given them;
12729	17	2	4	 and let the maiden that pleaseth the king be queen instead of Vashti.' And the thing pleased the king; and he did so.
12730	17	2	5	 There was a certain Jew in Shushan the castle, whose name was Mordecai the son of Jair the son of Shimei the son of Kish, a Benjamite,
12731	17	2	6	 who had been carried away from Jerusalem with the captives that had been carried away with Jeconiah king of Judah, whom Nebuchadnezzar the king of Babylon had carried away.
12732	17	2	7	 And he brought up Hadassah, that is, Esther, his uncle's daughter; for she had neither father nor mother, and the maiden was of beautiful form and fair to look on; and when her father and mother were dead, Mordecai took her for his own daughter.
12733	17	2	8	 So it came to pass, when the king's commandment and his decree was published, and when many maidens were gathered together unto Shushan the castle, to the custody of Hegai, that Esther was taken into the king's house, to the custody of Hegai, keeper of the women.
12734	17	2	9	 And the maiden pleased him, and she obtained kindness of him; and he speedily gave her her ointments, with her portions, and the seven maidens, who were meet to be given her out of the king's house; and he advanced her and her maidens to the best place in the house of the women.
12735	17	2	10	 Esther had not made known her people nor her kindred; for Mordecai had charged her that she should not tell it.
12736	17	2	11	 And Mordecai walked every day before the court of the women's house, to know how Esther did, and what would become of her.
12737	17	2	12	 Now when the turn of every maiden was come to go in to king Ahasuerus, after that it had been done to her according to the law for the women, twelve months--for so were the days of their anointing accomplished, to wit, six months with oil of myrrh, and six month with sweet odours, and with other ointments of the women--
12738	17	2	13	 when then the maiden came unto the king, whatsoever she desired was given her to go with her out of the house of the women unto the king's house.
12739	17	2	14	 In the evening she went, and on the morrow she returned into the second house of the women, to the custody of Shaashgaz, the king's chamberlain, who kept the concubines; she came in unto the king no more, except the king delighted in her, and she were called by name.
12740	17	2	15	 Now when the turn of Esther, the daughter of Abihail the uncle of Mordecai, who had taken her for his daughter, was come to go in unto the king, she required nothing but what Hegai the king's chamberlain, the keeper of the women, appointed. And Esther obtained favour in the sight of all them that looked upon her.
12741	17	2	16	 So Esther was taken unto king Ahasuerus into his house royal in the tenth month, which is the month Tebeth, in the seventh year of his reign.
12742	17	2	17	 And the king loved Esther above all the women, and she obtained grace and favour in his sight more than all the virgins; so that he set the royal crown upon her head, and made her queen instead of Vashti.
12743	17	2	18	 Then the king made a great feast unto all his princes and his servants, even Esther's feast; and he made a release to the provinces, and gave gifts, according to the bounty of the king.
12744	17	2	19	 And when the virgins were gathered together the second time, and Mordecai sat in the king's gate--
12745	17	2	20	 Esther had not yet made known her kindred nor her people; as Mordecai had charged her; for Esther did the commandment of Mordecai, like as when she was brought up with him--
12746	17	2	21	 in those days, while Mordecai sat in the king's gate, two of the king's chamberlains, Bigthan and Teresh, of those that kept the door, were wroth, and sought to lay hands on the king Ahasuerus.
12747	17	2	22	 And the thing became known to Mordecai, who told it unto Esther the queen; and Esther told the king thereof in Mordecai's name.
12748	17	2	23	 And when inquisition was made of the matter, and it was found to be so, they were both hanged on a tree; and it was written in the book of the chronicles before the king.
12749	17	3	1	 After these things did king Ahasuerus promote Haman the son of Hammedatha the Agagite, and advanced him, and set his seat above all the princes that were with him.
12750	17	3	2	 And all the king's servants, that were in the king's gate, bowed down, and prostrated themselves before Haman; for the king had so commanded concerning him. But Mordecai bowed not down, nor prostrated himself before him.
12751	17	3	3	 Then the king's servants, that were in the king's gate, said unto Mordecai: 'Why transgressest thou the king's commandment?'
12752	17	3	4	 Now it came to pass, when they spoke daily unto him, and he hearkened not unto them, that they told Haman, to see whether Mordecai's words would stand; for he had told them that he was a Jew.
12753	17	3	5	 And when Haman saw that Mordecai bowed not down, nor prostrated himself before him, then was Haman full of wrath.
12754	17	3	6	 But it seemed contemptible in his eyes to lay hands on Mordecai alone; for they had made known to him the people of Mordecai; wherefore Haman sought to destroy all the Jews that were throughout the whole kingdom of Ahasuerus, even the people of Mordecai.
12755	17	3	7	 In the first month, which is the month Nisan, in the twelfth year of king Ahasuerus, they cast pur, that is, the lot, before Haman from day to day, and from month to month, to the twelfth month, which is the month Adar.
12756	17	3	8	 And Haman said unto king Ahasuerus: 'There is a certain people scattered abroad and dispersed among the peoples in all the provinces of thy kingdom; and their laws are diverse from those of every people; neither keep they the king's laws; therefore it profiteth not the king to suffer them.
12757	17	3	9	 If it please the king, let it be written that they be destroyed; and I will pay ten thousand talents of silver into the hands of those that have the charge of the king's business, to bring it into the king's treasuries.'
12758	17	3	10	 And the king took his ring from his hand, and gave it unto Haman the son of Hammedatha the Agagite, the Jews' enemy.
12759	17	3	11	 And the king said unto Haman: 'The silver is given to thee, the people also, to do with them as it seemeth good to thee.'
12760	17	3	12	 Then were the king's scribes called in the first month, on the thirteenth day thereof, and there was written, according to all that Haman commanded, unto the king's satraps, and to the governors that were over every province, and to the princes of every people; to every province according to the writing thereof, and to every people after their language; in the name of king Ahasuerus was it written, and it was sealed with the king's ring.
12761	17	3	13	 And letters were sent by posts into all the king's provinces, to destroy, to slay, and to cause to perish, all Jews, both young and old, little children and women, in one day, even upon the thirteenth day of the twelfth month, which is the month Adar, and to take the spoil of them for a prey.
12762	17	3	14	 The copy of the writing, to be given out for a decree in every province, was to be published unto all peoples, that they should be ready against that day.
12763	17	3	15	 The posts went forth in haste by the king's commandment, and the decree was given out in Shushan the castle; and the king and Haman sat down to drink; but the city of Shushan was perplexed.
12764	17	4	1	 Now when Mordecai knew all that was done, Mordecai rent his clothes, and put on sackcloth with ashes, and went out into the midst of the city, and cried with a loud and a bitter cry;
12765	17	4	2	 and he came even before the king's gate; for none might enter within the king's gate clothed with sackcloth.
12766	17	4	3	 And in every province, whithersoever the king's commandment and his decree came, there was great mourning among the Jews, and fasting, and weeping, and wailing; and many lay in sackcloth and ashes.
12767	17	4	4	 And Esther's maidens and her chamberlains came and told it her; and the queen was exceedingly pained; and she sent raiment to clothe Mordecai; and to take his sackcloth from off him; but he accepted it not.
12768	17	4	5	 Then called Esther for Hathach, one of the king's chamberlains, whom he had appointed to attend upon her, and charged him to go to Mordecai, to know what this was, and why it was.
12769	17	4	6	 So Hathach went forth to Mordecai unto the broad place of the city, which was before the king's gate.
12770	17	4	7	 And Mordecai told him of all that had happened unto him, and the exact sum of the money that Haman had promised to pay to the king's treasuries for the Jews, to destroy them.
12771	17	4	8	 Also he gave him the copy of the writing of the decree that was given out in Shushan to destroy them, to show it unto Esther, and to declare it unto her; and to charge her that she should go in unto the king, to make supplication unto him, and to make request before him, for her people.
12772	17	4	9	 And Hathach came and told Esther the words of Mordecai.
12773	17	4	10	 Then Esther spoke unto Hathach, and gave him a message unto Mordecai:
12774	17	4	11	 'All the king's servants, and the people of the king's provinces, do know, that whosoever, whether man or woman, shall come unto the king into the inner court, who is not called, there is one law for him, that he be put to death, except such to whom the king shall hold out the golden sceptre, that he may live; but I have not been called to come in unto the king these thirty days.'
12775	17	4	12	 And they told to Mordecai Esther's words.
12776	17	4	13	 Then Mordecai bade them to return answer unto Esther: 'Think not with thyself that thou shalt escape in the king's house, more than all the Jews.
12777	17	4	14	 For if thou altogether holdest thy peace at this time, then will relief and deliverance arise to the Jews from another place, but thou and thy father's house will perish; and who knoweth whether thou art not come to royal estate for such a time as this?'
12778	17	4	15	 Then Esther bade them return answer unto Mordecai:
12779	17	4	16	 'Go, gather together all the Jews that are present in Shushan, and fast ye for me, and neither eat nor drink three days, night or day; I also and my maidens will fast in like manner; and so will I go in unto the king, which is not according to the law; and if I perish, I perish.'
12780	17	4	17	 So Mordecai went his way, and did according to all that Esther had commanded him.
12781	17	5	1	 Now it came to pass on the third day, that Esther put on her royal apparel, and stood in the inner court of the king's house, over against the king's house; and the king sat upon his royal throne in the royal house, over against the entrance of the house.
12782	17	5	2	 And it was so, when the king saw Esther the queen standing in the court, that she obtained favour in his sight; and the king held out to Esther the golden sceptre that was in his hand. So Esther drew near, and touched the top of the sceptre.
12783	17	5	3	 Then said the king unto her: 'What wilt thou, queen Esther? for whatever thy request, even to the half of the kingdom, it shall be given thee.'
12784	17	5	4	 And Esther said: 'If it seem good unto the king, let the king and Haman come this day unto the banquet that I have prepared for him.'
12785	17	5	5	 Then the king said: 'Cause Haman to make haste, that it may be done as Esther hath said.' So the king and Haman came to the banquet that Esther had prepared.
12786	17	5	6	 And the king said unto Esther at the banquet of wine: 'Whatever thy petition, it shall be granted thee; and whatever thy request, even to the half of the kingdom, it shall be performed.'
12787	17	5	7	 Then answered Esther, and said: 'My petition and my request is--
12788	17	5	8	 if I have found favour in the sight of the king, and if it please the king to grant my petition, and to perform my request--let the king and Haman come to the banquet that I shall prepare for them, and I will do to-morrow as the king hath said.'
12789	17	5	9	 Then went Haman forth that day joyful and glad of heart; but when Haman saw Mordecai in the king's gate, that he stood not up, nor moved for him, Haman was filled with wrath against Mordecai.
12790	17	5	10	 Nevertheless Haman refrained himself, and went home; and he sent and fetched his friends and Zeresh his wife.
12791	17	5	11	 And Haman recounted unto them the glory of his riches, and the multitude of his children, and everything as to how the king had promoted him, and how he had advanced him above the princes and servants of the king.
12792	17	5	12	 Haman said moreover: 'Yea, Esther the queen did let no man come in with the king unto the banquet that she had prepared but myself; and to-morrow also am I invited by her together with the king.
12793	17	5	13	 Yet all this availeth me nothing, so long as I see Mordecai the Jew sitting at the king's gate.'
12794	17	5	14	 Then said Zeresh his wife and all his friends unto him: 'Let a gallows be made of fifty cubits high, and in the morning speak thou unto the king that Mordecai may be hanged thereon; then go thou in merrily with the king unto the banquet.' And the thing pleased Haman; and he caused the gallows to be made.
12795	17	6	1	 On that night could not the king sleep; and he commanded to bring the book of records of the chronicles, and they were read before the king.
12796	17	6	2	 And it was found written, that Mordecai had told of Bigthana and Teresh, two of the king's chamberlains, of those that kept the door, who had sought to lay hands on the king Ahasuerus.
12797	17	6	3	 And the king said: 'What honour and dignity hath been done to Mordecai for this?' Then said the king's servants that ministered unto him: 'There is nothing done for him.'
12798	17	6	4	 And the king said: 'Who is in the court?' --Now Haman was come into the outer court of the king's house, to speak unto the king to hang Mordecai on the gallows that he had prepared for him.--
12799	17	6	5	 And the king's servants said unto him: 'Behold, Haman standeth in the court.' And the king said: 'Let him come in.'
12800	17	6	6	 So Haman came in. And the king said unto him: 'What shall be done unto the man whom the king delighteth to honour?' --Now Haman said in his heart: 'Whom would the king delight to honour besides myself?'--
12801	17	6	7	 And Haman said unto the king: 'For the man whom the king delighteth to honour,
12802	17	6	8	 let royal apparel be brought which the king useth to wear, and the horse that the king rideth upon, and on whose head a crown royal is set;
12803	17	6	9	 and let the apparel and the horse be delivered to the hand of one of the king's most noble princes, that they may array the man therewith whom the king delighteth to honour, and cause him to ride on horseback through the street of the city, and proclaim before him: Thus shall it be done to the man whom the king delighteth to honour.'
12804	17	6	10	 Then the king said to Haman: 'Make haste, and take the apparel and the horse, as thou hast said, and do even so to Mordecai the Jew, that sitteth at the king's gate; let nothing fail of all that thou hast spoken.'
12805	17	6	11	 Then took Haman the apparel and the horse, and arrayed Mordecai, and caused him to ride through the street of the city, and proclaimed before him: 'Thus shall it be done unto the man whom the king delighteth to honour.'
12806	17	6	12	 And Mordecai returned to the king's gate. But Haman hasted to his house, mourning and having his head covered.
12807	17	6	13	 And Haman recounted unto Zeresh his wife and all his friends every thing that had befallen him. Then said his wise men and Zeresh his wife unto him: 'If Mordecai, before whom thou hast begun to fall, be of the seed of the Jews, thou shalt not prevail against him, but shalt surely fall before him.'
12808	17	6	14	 While they were yet talking with him, came the king's chamberlains, and hastened to bring Haman unto the banquet that Esther had prepared.
12809	17	7	1	 So the king and Haman came to banquet with Esther the queen.
12810	17	7	2	 And the king said again unto Esther on the second day at the banquet of wine: 'Whatever thy petition, queen Esther, it shall be granted thee; and whatever thy request, even to the half of the kingdom, it shall be performed.'
12811	17	7	3	 Then Esther the queen answered and said: 'If I have found favour in thy sight, O king, and if it please the king, let my life be given me at my petition, and my people at my request;
12812	17	7	4	 for we are sold, I and my people, to be destroyed, to be slain, and to perish. But if we had been sold for bondmen and bondwomen, I had held my peace, for the adversary is not worthy that the king be endamaged.'
12813	17	7	5	 Then spoke the king Ahasuerus and said unto Esther the queen: 'Who is he, and where is he, that durst presume in his heart to do so?'
12814	17	7	6	 And Esther said: 'An adversary and an enemy, even this wicked Haman.' Then Haman was terrified before the king and the queen.
12815	17	7	7	 And the king arose in his wrath from the banquet of wine and went into the palace garden; but Haman remained to make request for his life to Esther the queen; for he saw that there was evil determined against him by the king.
12816	17	7	8	 Then the king returned out of the palace garden into the place of the banquet of wine; and Haman was fallen upon the couch whereon Esther was. Then said the king: 'Will he even force the queen before me in the house?' As the word went out of the king's mouth, they covered Haman's face.
12817	17	7	9	 Then said Harbonah, one of the chamberlains that were before the king: 'Behold also, the gallows fifty cubits high, which Haman hath made for Mordecai, who spoke good for the king, standeth in the house of Haman.' And the king said: 'Hang him thereon.'
12818	17	7	10	 So they hanged Haman on the gallows that he had prepared for Mordecai. Then was the king's wrath assuaged.
12819	17	8	1	 On that day did the king Ahasuerus give the house of Haman the Jews' enemy unto Esther the queen. And Mordecai came before the king; for Esther had told what he was unto her.
12820	17	8	2	 And the king took off his ring, which he had taken from Haman, and gave it unto Mordecai. And Esther set Mordecai over the house of Haman.
12821	17	8	3	 And Esther spoke yet again before the king, and fell down at his feet, and besought him with tears to put away the mischief of Haman the Agagite, and his device that he had devised against the Jews.
12822	17	8	4	 Then the king held out to Esther the golden sceptre. So Esther arose, and stood before the king.
12823	17	8	5	 And she said: 'If it please the king, and if I have found favour in his sight, and the thing seem right before the king, and I be pleasing in his eyes, let it be written to reverse the letters devised by Haman the son of Hammedatha the Agagite, which he wrote to destroy the Jews that are in all the king's provinces;
12824	17	8	6	 for how can I endure to see the evil that shall come unto my people? or how can I endure to see the destruction of my kindred?'
12825	17	8	7	 Then the king Ahasuerus said unto Esther the queen and to Mordecai the Jew: 'Behold, I have given Esther the house of Haman, and him they have hanged upon the gallows, because he laid his hand upon the Jews.
12826	17	8	8	 Write ye also concerning the Jews, as it liketh you, in the king's name, and seal it with the king's ring; for the writing which is written in the king's name, and sealed with the king's ring, may no man reverse.'
12827	17	8	9	 Then were the king's scribes called at that time, in the third month, which is the month Sivan, on the three and twentieth day thereof; and it was written according to all that Mordecai commanded concerning the Jews, even to the satraps, and the governors and princes of the provinces which are from India unto Ethiopia, a hundred twenty and seven provinces, unto every province according to the writing thereof, and unto every people after their language, and to the Jews according to their writing, and according to their language.
12828	17	8	10	 And they wrote in the name of king Ahasuerus, and sealed it with the king's ring, and sent letters by posts on horseback, riding on swift steeds that were used in the king's service, bred of the stud;
12829	17	8	11	 that the king had granted the Jews that were in every city to gather themselves together, and to stand for their life, to destroy, and to slay, and to cause to perish, all the forces of the people and province that would assault them, their little ones and women, and to take the spoil of them for a prey,
12830	17	8	12	 upon one day in all the provinces of king Ahasuerus, namely, upon the thirteenth day of the twelfth month, which is the month Adar.
12831	17	8	13	 The copy of the writing, to be given out for a decree in every province, was to be published unto all the peoples, and that the Jews should be ready against that day to avenge themselves on their enemies.
12832	17	8	14	 So the posts that rode upon swift steeds that were used in the king's service went out, being hastened and pressed on by the king's commandment; and the decree was given out in Shushan the castle.
12833	17	8	15	 And Mordecai went forth from the presence of the king in royal apparel of blue and white, and with a great crown of gold, and with a rob of fine linen and purple; and the city of Shushan shouted and was glad.
12834	17	8	16	 The Jews had light and gladness, and joy and honour.
12835	17	8	17	 And in every province, and in every city, whithersoever the king's commandment and his decree came, the Jews had gladness and joy, a feast and a good day. And many from among the peoples of the land became Jews; for the fear of the Jews was fallen upon them.
12836	17	9	1	 Now in the twelfth month, which is the month Adar, on the thirteenth day of the same, when the king's commandment and his decree drew near to be put in execution, in the day that the enemies of the Jews hoped to have rule over them; whereas it was turned to the contrary, that the Jews had rule over them that hated them;
12837	17	9	2	 the Jews gathered themselves together in their cities throughout all the provinces of the king Ahasuerus, to lay hand on such as sought their hurt; and no man could withstand them; for the fear of them was fallen upon all the peoples.
12838	17	9	3	 And all the princes of the provinces, and the satraps, and the governors, and they that did the king's business, helped the Jews; because the fear of Mordecai was fallen upon them.
12839	17	9	4	 For Mordecai was great in the king's house, and his fame went forth throughout all the provinces; for the man Mordecai waxed greater and greater.
12840	17	9	5	 And the Jews smote all their enemies with the stroke of the sword, and with slaughter and destruction, and did what they would unto them that hated them.
12841	17	9	6	 And in Shushan the castle the Jews slew and destroyed five hundred men.
12842	17	9	7	 And Parshandatha, and Dalphon, and Aspatha,
12843	17	9	8	 and Poratha, and Adalia, and Aridatha,
12844	17	9	9	 and Parmashta, and Arisai, and Aridai, and Vaizatha,
12845	17	9	10	 the ten sons of Haman the son of Hammedatha, the Jews' enemy, slew they; but on the spoil they laid not their hand.
12846	17	9	11	 On that day the number of those that were slain in Shushan the castle was brought before the king.
12847	17	9	12	 And the king said unto Esther the queen: 'The Jews have slain and destroyed five hundred men in Shushan the castle, and the ten sons of Haman; what then have they done in the rest of the king's provinces! Now whatever thy petition, it shall be granted thee; and whatever thy request further, it shall be done.'
12848	17	9	13	 Then said Esther: 'If it please the king, let it be granted to the Jews that are in Shushan to do to-morrow also according unto this day's decree, and let Haman's ten sons be hanged upon the gallows.'
12849	17	9	14	 And the king commanded it so to be done; and a decree was given out in Shushan; and they hanged Haman's ten sons.
12850	17	9	15	 And the Jews that were in Shushan gathered themselves together on the fourteenth day also of the month Adar, and slew three hundred men in Shushan; but on the spoil they laid not their hand.
12851	17	9	16	 And the other Jews that were in the king's provinces gathered themselves together, and stood for their lives, and had rest from their enemies, and slew of them that hated them seventy and five thousand--but on the spoil they laid not their hand--
12852	17	9	17	 on the thirteenth day of the month Adar, and on the fourteenth day of the same they rested, and made it a day of feasting and gladness.
12853	17	9	18	 But the Jews that were in Shushan assembled together on the thirteenth day thereof, and on the fourteenth thereof; and on the fifteenth day of the same they rested, and made it a day of feasting and gladness.
12854	17	9	19	 Therefore do the Jews of the villages, that dwell in the unwalled towns, make the fourteenth day of the month Adar a day of gladness and feasting, and a good day, and of sending portions one to another.
12855	17	9	20	 And Mordecai wrote these things, and sent letters unto all the Jews that were in all the provinces of the king Ahasuerus, both nigh and far,
12856	17	9	21	 to enjoin them that they should keep the fourteenth day of the month Adar, and the fifteenth day of the same, yearly,
12857	17	9	22	 the days wherein the Jews had rest from their enemies, and the month which was turned unto them from sorrow to gladness, and from mourning into a good day; that they should make them days of feasting and gladness, and of sending portions one to another, and gifts to the poor.
12858	17	9	23	 And the Jews took upon them to do as they had begun, and as Mordecai had written unto them;
12859	17	9	24	 because Haman the son of Hammedatha, the Agagite, the enemy of all the Jews, had devised against the Jews to destroy them, and had cast pur, that is, the lot, to discomfit them, and to destroy them;
12860	17	9	25	 but when she came before the king, he commanded by letters that his wicked device, which he had devised against the Jews, should return upon his own head; and that he and his sons should be hanged on the gallows.
12861	17	9	26	 Wherefore they called these days Purim, after the name of pur. Therefore because of all the words of this letter, and of that which they had seen concerning this matter, and that which had come unto them,
12862	17	9	27	 the Jews ordained, and took upon them, and upon their seed, and upon all such as joined themselves unto them, so as it should not fail, that they would keep these two days according to the writing thereof, and according to the appointed time thereof, every year;
12863	17	9	28	 and that these days should be remembered and kept throughout every generation, every family, every province, and every city; and that these days of Purim should not fail from among the Jews, nor the memorial of them perish from their seed.
12864	17	9	29	 Then Esther the queen, the daughter of Abihail, and Mordecai the Jew, wrote down all the acts of power, to confirm this second letter of Purim.
12865	17	9	30	 And he sent letters unto all the Jews, to the hundred twenty and seven provinces of the kingdom of Ahasuerus, with words of peace and truth,
12866	17	9	31	 to confirm these days of Purim in their appointed times, according as Mordecai the Jew and Esther the queen had enjoined them, and as they had ordained for themselves and for their seed, the matters of the fastings and their cry.
12867	17	9	32	 And the commandment of Esther confirmed these matters of Purim; and it was written in the book.
12868	17	10	1	 And the king Ahasuerus laid a tribute upon the land, and upon the isles of the sea.
12869	17	10	2	 And all the acts of his power and of his might, and the full account of the greatness of Mordecai, how the king advanced him, are they not written in the book of the chronicles of the kings of Media and Persia?
12870	17	10	3	 For Mordecai the Jew was next unto king Ahasuerus, and great among the Jews, and accepted of the multitude of his brethren; seeking the good of his people and speaking peace to all his seed.
12871	18	1	1	 THERE was a man in the land of Uz, whose name was Job; and that man was whole-hearted and upright, and one that feared God, and shunned evil.
12872	18	1	2	 And there were born unto him seven sons and three daughters.
12873	18	1	3	 His possessions also were seven thousand sheep, and three thousand camels, and five hundred yoke of oxen, and five hundred she-asses, and a very great household; so that this man was the greatest of all the children of the east.
12874	18	1	4	 And his sons used to go and hold a feast in the house of each one upon his day; and they would send and invite their three sisters to eat and to drink with them.
12875	18	1	5	 And it was so, when the days of their feasting were gone about, that Job sent and sanctified them, and rose up early in the morning, and offered burnt-offerings according to the number of them all; for Job said: 'It may be that my sons have sinned, and blasphemed God in their hearts.' Thus did Job continually.
12876	18	1	6	 Now it fell upon a day, that the sons of God came to present themselves before the LORD, and Satan came also among them.
12877	18	1	7	 And the LORD said unto Satan: 'Whence comest thou?' Then Satan answered the LORD, and said: 'From going to and fro in the earth, and from walking up and down in it.'
12878	18	1	8	 And the LORD said unto Satan: 'Hast thou considered My servant Job, that there is none like him in the earth, a whole-hearted and an upright man, one that feareth God, and shunneth evil?'
12879	18	1	9	 Then Satan answered the LORD, and said: 'Doth Job fear God for nought?
12880	18	1	10	 Hast not Thou made a hedge about him, and about his house, and about all that he hath, on every side? Thou hast blessed the work of his hands, and his possessions are increased in the land.
12881	18	1	11	 But put forth Thy hand now, and touch all that he hath, surely he will blaspheme Thee to Thy face.'
12882	18	1	12	 And the LORD said unto Satan: 'Behold, all that he hath is in thy power; only upon himself put not forth thy hand.' So Satan went forth from the presence of the LORD.
12883	18	1	13	 And it fell on a day when his sons and his daughters were eating and drinking wine in their eldest brother's house,
12884	18	1	14	 that there came a messenger unto Job, and said: 'The oxen were plowing, and the asses feeding beside them;
12885	18	1	15	 and the Sabeans made a raid, and took them away; yea, they have slain the servants with the edge of the sword; and I only am escaped alone to tell thee.'
12886	18	1	16	 While he was yet speaking, there came also another, and said: 'A fire of God is fallen from heaven, and hath burned up the sheep, and the servants, and consumed them; and I only am escaped alone to tell thee.'
12887	18	1	17	 While he was yet speaking, there came also another, and said: 'The Chaldeans set themselves in three bands, and fell upon the camels, and have taken them away, yea, and slain the servants with the edge of the sword; and I only am escaped alone to tell thee.'
12888	18	1	18	 While he was yet speaking, there came also another, and said: 'Thy sons and thy daughters were eating and drinking wine in their eldest brother's house;
12889	18	1	19	 And, behold, there came a great wind from across the wilderness, and smote the four corners of the house, and it fell upon the young people, and they are dead; and I only am escaped alone to tell thee.'
12890	18	1	20	 Then Job arose, and rent his mantle, and shaved his head, and fell down upon the ground, and worshipped;
12891	18	1	21	 And he said; naked came I out of my mother's womb, and naked shall I return thither; the LORD gave, and the LORD hath taken away; blessed be the name of the LORD.
12892	18	1	22	 For all this Job sinned not, nor ascribed aught unseemly to God.
12893	18	2	1	 Again it fell upon a day, that the sons of God came to present themselves before the LORD, and Satan came also among them to present himself before the LORD.
12894	18	2	2	 And the LORD said unto Satan: 'From whence comest thou?' And Satan answered the LORD, and said: 'From going to and fro in the earth, and from walking up and down in it.'
12895	18	2	3	 And the LORD said unto Satan: 'Hast thou considered my servant Job, that there is none like him in the earth, a whole-hearted and an upright man, one that feareth God, and shunneth evil? and he still holdeth fast his integrity, although thou didst move Me against him, to destroy him without cause.'
12896	18	2	4	 And Satan answered the LORD, and said: 'Skin for skin, yea, all that a man hath will he give for his life.
12897	18	2	5	 But put forth Thy hand now, and touch his bone and his flesh, surely he will blaspheme Thee to Thy face.'
12898	18	2	6	 And the LORD said unto Satan: 'Behold, he is in thy hand; only spare his life.'
12899	18	2	7	 So Satan went forth from the presence of the LORD, and smote Job with sore boils from the sole of his foot even unto his crown.
12900	18	2	8	 And he took him a potsherd to scrape himself therewith; and he sat among the ashes.
12901	18	2	9	 Then said his wife unto him: 'Dost thou still hold fast thine integrity? blaspheme God, and die.'
12902	18	2	10	 But he said unto her: 'Thou speakest as one of the impious women speaketh. What? shall we receive good at the hand of God, and shall we not receive evil?' For all this did not Job sin with his lips.
12903	18	2	11	 Now when Job's three friends heard of all this evil that was come upon him, they came every one from his own place, Eliphaz the Temanite, and Bildad the Shuhite, and Zophar the Naamathite; and they made an appointment together to come to bemoan him and to comfort him.
12904	18	2	12	 And when they lifted up their eyes afar off, and knew him not, they lifted up their voice, and wept; and they rent every one his mantle, and threw dust upon their heads toward heaven.
12905	18	2	13	 So they sat down with him upon the ground seven days and seven nights, and none spoke a word unto him; for they saw that his grief was very great.
12906	18	3	1	 After this opened Job his mouth, and cursed his day.
12907	18	3	2	 And Job spoke, and said:
12908	18	3	3	 Let the day perish wherein I was born, and the night wherein it was said: 'A man-child is brought forth.'
12909	18	3	4	 Let that day be darkness; let not God inquire after it from above, neither let the light shine upon it.
12910	18	3	5	 Let darkness and the shadow of death claim it for their own; let a cloud dwell upon it; let all that maketh black the day terrify it.
12911	18	3	6	 As for that night, let thick darkness seize upon it; let it not rejoice among the days of the year; let it not come into the number of the months.
12912	18	3	7	 Lo, let that night be desolate; let no joyful voice come therein.
12913	18	3	8	 Let them curse it that curse the day, who are ready to rouse up leviathan.
12914	18	3	9	 Let the stars of the twilight thereof be dark; let it look for light, but have none; neither let it behold the eyelids of the morning;
12915	18	3	10	 Because it shut not up the doors of my mother's womb, nor hid trouble from mine eyes.
12916	18	3	11	 Why died I not from the womb? Why did I not perish at birth?
12917	18	3	12	 Why did the knees receive me? And wherefore the breasts, that I should suck?
12918	18	3	13	 For now should I have lain still and been quiet; I should have slept; then had I been at rest--
12919	18	3	14	 With kings and counsellors of the earth, who built up waste places for themselves;
12920	18	3	15	 Or with princes that had gold, who filled their houses with silver;
12921	18	3	16	 Or as a hidden untimely birth I had not been; as infants that never saw light.
12922	18	3	17	 There the wicked cease from troubling; and there the weary are at rest.
12923	18	3	18	 There the prisoners are at ease together; they hear not the voice of the taskmaster.
12924	18	3	19	 The small and great are there alike; and the servant is free from his master.
12925	18	3	20	 Wherewith is light given to him that is in misery, and life unto the bitter in soul--
12926	18	3	21	 Who long for death, but it cometh not; and dig for it more than for hid treasures;
12927	18	3	22	 Who rejoice unto exultation, and are glad, when they can find the grave?--
12928	18	3	23	 To a man whose way is hid, and whom God hath hedged in?
12929	18	3	24	 For my sighing cometh instead of my food, and my roarings are poured out like water.
12930	18	3	25	 For the thing which I did fear is come upon me, and that which I was afraid of hath overtaken me.
12931	18	3	26	 I was not at ease, neither was I quiet, neither had I rest; but trouble came.
12932	18	4	1	 Then answered Eliphaz the Temanite, and said:
12933	18	4	2	 If one venture a word unto thee, wilt thou be weary? But who can withhold himself from speaking?
12934	18	4	3	 Behold, thou hast instructed many, and thou hast strengthened the weak hands.
12935	18	4	4	 Thy words have upholden him that was falling, and thou hast strengthened the feeble knees.
12936	18	4	5	 But now it is come upon thee, and thou art weary; it toucheth thee, and thou art affrighted.
12937	18	4	6	 Is not thy fear of God thy confidence, and thy hope the integrity of thy ways?
12938	18	4	7	 Remember, I pray thee, who ever perished, being innocent? Or where were the upright cut off?
12939	18	4	8	 According as I have seen, they that plow iniquity, and sow mischief, reap the same.
12940	18	4	9	 By the breath of God they perish, and by the blast of His anger are they consumed.
12941	18	4	10	 The lion roareth, and the fierce lion howleth--yet the teeth of the young lions are broken.
12942	18	4	11	 The old lion perisheth for lack of prey, and the whelps of the lioness are scattered abroad.
12943	18	4	12	 Now a word was secretly brought to me, and mine ear received a whisper thereof.
12944	18	4	13	 In thoughts from the visions of the night, when deep sleep falleth on men,
12945	18	4	14	 Fear came upon me, and trembling, and all my bones were made to shake.
12946	18	4	15	 Then a spirit passed before my face, that made the hair of my flesh to stand up.
12947	18	4	16	 It stood still, but I could not discern the appearance thereof; a form was before mine eyes; I heard a still voice:
12948	18	4	17	 'Shall mortal man be just before God? Shall a man be pure before his Maker?
12949	18	4	18	 Behold, He putteth no trust in His servants, and His angels He chargeth with folly;
12950	18	4	19	 How much more them that dwell in houses of clay, whose foundation is in the dust, who are crushed before the moth!
12951	18	4	20	 Betwixt morning and evening they are shattered; they perish for ever without any regarding it.
12952	18	4	21	 Is not their tent-cord plucked up within them? They die, and that without wisdom.'
12953	18	5	1	 Call now; is there any that will answer thee? And to which of the holy ones wilt thou turn?
12954	18	5	2	 For anger killeth the foolish man, and envy slayeth the silly one.
12955	18	5	3	 I have seen the foolish taking root; but suddenly I beheld his habitation cursed.
12956	18	5	4	 His children are far from safety, and are crushed in the gate, with none to deliver them.
12957	18	5	5	 Whose harvest the hungry eateth up, and taketh it even out of the thorns, and the snare gapeth for their substance.
12958	18	5	6	 For affliction cometh not forth from the dust, neither doth trouble spring out of the ground;
12959	18	5	7	 But man is born unto trouble, as the sparks fly upward.
12960	18	5	8	 But as for me, I would seek unto God, and unto God would I commit my cause;
12961	18	5	9	 Who doeth great things and unsearchable, marvellous things without number;
12962	18	5	10	 Who giveth rain upon the earth, and sendeth waters upon the fields;
12963	18	5	11	 So that He setteth up on high those that are low, and those that mourn are exalted to safety.
12964	18	5	12	 He frustrateth the devices of the crafty, so that their hands can perform nothing substantial.
12965	18	5	13	 He taketh the wise in their own craftiness; and the counsel of the wily is carried headlong.
12966	18	5	14	 They meet with darkness in the day-time, and grope at noonday as in the night.
12967	18	5	15	 But He saveth from the sword of their mouth, even the needy from the hand of the mighty.
12968	18	5	16	 So the poor hath hope, and iniquity stoppeth her mouth.
12969	18	5	17	 Behold, happy is the man whom God correcteth; therefore despise not thou the chastening of the Almighty.
12970	18	5	18	 For He maketh sore, and bindeth up; He woundeth, and His hands make whole.
12971	18	5	19	 He will deliver thee in six troubles; yea, in seven there shall no evil touch thee.
12972	18	5	20	 In famine He will redeem thee from death; and in war from the power of the sword.
12973	18	5	21	 Thou shalt be hid from the scourge of the tongue; neither shalt thou be afraid of destruction when it cometh.
12974	18	5	22	 At destruction and famine thou shalt laugh; neither shalt thou be afraid of the beasts of the earth.
12975	18	5	23	 For thou shalt be in league with the stones of the field; and the beasts of the field shall be at peace with thee.
12976	18	5	24	 And thou shalt know that thy tent is in peace; and thou shalt visit thy habitation, and shalt miss nothing.
12977	18	5	25	 Thou shalt know also that thy seed shall be great, and thine offspring as the grass of the earth.
12978	18	5	26	 Thou shalt come to thy grave in a ripe age, like as a shock of corn cometh in in its season.
12979	18	5	27	 Lo this, we have searched it, so it is; hear it, and know thou it for thy good.
12980	18	6	1	 Then Job answered and said:
12981	18	6	2	 Oh that my vexation were but weighed, and my calamity laid in the balances altogether!
12982	18	6	3	 For now it would be heavier than the sand of the seas; therefore are my words broken.
12983	18	6	4	 For the arrows of the Almighty are within me, the poison whereof my spirit drinketh up; the terrors of God do set themselves in array against me.
12984	18	6	5	 Doth the wild ass bray when he hath grass? or loweth the ox over his fodder?
12985	18	6	6	 Can that which hath no savour be eaten without salt? or is there any taste in the juice of mallows?
12986	18	6	7	 My soul refuseth to touch them; they are as the sickness of my flesh.
12987	18	6	8	 Oh that I might have my request, and that God would grant me the thing that I long for!
12988	18	6	9	 Even that it would please God to crush me; that He would let loose His hand, and cut me off!
12989	18	6	10	 Then should I yet have comfort; yea, I would exult in pain, though He spare not; for I have not denied the words of the Holy One.
12990	18	6	11	 What is my strength, that I should wait? and what is mine end, that I should be patient?
12991	18	6	12	 Is my strength the strength of stones? or is my flesh of brass?
12992	18	6	13	 Is it that I have no help in me, and that sound wisdom is driven quite from me?
12993	18	6	14	 To him that is ready to faint kindness is due from his friend, even to him that forsaketh the fear of the Almighty.
12994	18	6	15	 My brethren have dealt deceitfully as a brook, as the channel of brooks that overflow,
12995	18	6	16	 Which are black by reason of the ice, and wherein the snow hideth itself;
12996	18	6	17	 What time they wax warm, they vanish, when it is hot, they are consumed out of their place.
12997	18	6	18	 The paths of their way do wind, they go up into the waste, and are lost.
12998	18	6	19	 The caravans of Tema looked, the companies of Sheba waited for them--
12999	18	6	20	 They were ashamed because they had hoped; they came thither, and were confounded.
13000	18	6	21	 For now ye are become His; ye see a terror, and are afraid.
13001	18	6	22	 Did I say: 'Give unto me'? or: 'Offer a present for me of your substance'?
13002	18	6	23	 or: 'Deliver me from the adversary's hand'? or: 'Redeem me from the hand of the oppressors'?
13003	18	6	24	 Teach me, and I will hold my peace; and cause me to understand wherein I have erred.
13004	18	6	25	 How forcible are words of uprightness! But what doth your arguing argue?
13005	18	6	26	 Do ye hold words to be an argument, but the speeches of one that is desperate to be wind?
13006	18	6	27	 Yea, ye would cast lots upon the fatherless, and dig a pit for your friend.
13007	18	6	28	 Now therefore be pleased to look upon me; for surely I shall not lie to your face.
13008	18	6	29	 Return, I pray you, let there be no injustice; yea, return again, my cause is righteous.
13009	18	6	30	 Is there injustice on my tongue? Cannot my taste discern crafty devices?
13010	18	7	1	 Is there not a time of service to man upon earth? And are not his days like the days of a hireling?
13011	18	7	2	 As a servant that eagerly longeth for the shadow, and as a hireling that looketh for his wages;
13012	18	7	3	 So am I made to possess--months of vanity, and wearisome nights are appointed to me.
13013	18	7	4	 When I lie down, I say: 'When shall I arise?' But the night is long, and I am full of tossings to and fro unto the dawning of the day.
13014	18	7	5	 My flesh is clothed with worms and clods of dust; my skin closeth up and breaketh out afresh.
13015	18	7	6	 My days are swifter than a weaver's shuttle, and are spent without hope.
13016	18	7	7	 O remember that my life is a breath; mine eye shall no more see good.
13017	18	7	8	 The eye of him that seeth me shall behold me no more; while Thine eyes are upon me, I am gone.
13018	18	7	9	 As the cloud is consumed and vanisheth away, so he that goeth down to the grave shall come up no more.
13019	18	7	10	 He shall return no more to his house, neither shall his place know him any more.
13020	18	7	11	 Therefore I will not refrain my mouth; I will speak in the anguish of my spirit; I will complain in the bitterness of my soul.
13021	18	7	12	 Am I a sea, or a sea-monster, that Thou settest a watch over me?
13022	18	7	13	 When I say: 'My bed shall comfort me, my couch shall ease my complaint';
13023	18	7	14	 Then Thou scarest me with dreams, and terrifiest me through visions;
13024	18	7	15	 So that my soul chooseth strangling, and death rather than these my bones.
13025	18	7	16	 I loathe it; I shall not live alway; let me alone; for my days are vanity.
13026	18	7	17	 What is man, that Thou shouldest magnify him, and that Thou shouldest set Thy heart upon him,
13027	18	7	18	 And that Thou shouldest remember him every morning, and try him every moment?
13028	18	7	19	 How long wilt Thou not look away from me, nor let me alone till I swallow down my spittle?
13029	18	7	20	 If I have sinned, what do I unto Thee, O Thou watcher of men? Why hast Thou set me as a mark for Thee, so that I am a burden to myself?
13030	18	7	21	 And why dost Thou not pardon my transgression, and take away mine iniquity? For now shall I lie down in the dust; and Thou wilt seek me, but I shall not be.
13031	18	8	1	 Then answered Bildad the Shuhite, and said:
13032	18	8	2	 How long wilt thou speak these things, seeing that the words of thy mouth are as a mighty wind?
13033	18	8	3	 Doth God pervert judgment? Or doth the Almighty pervert justice?
13034	18	8	4	 If thy children sinned against Him, He delivered them into the hand of their transgression.
13035	18	8	5	 If thou wouldest seek earnestly unto God, and make thy supplication to the Almighty;
13036	18	8	6	 If thou wert pure and upright; surely now He would awake for thee, and make the habitation of thy righteousness prosperous.
13037	18	8	7	 And though thy beginning was small, yet thy end should greatly increase.
13038	18	8	8	 For inquire, I pray thee, of the former generation, and apply thyself to that which their fathers have searched out--
13039	18	8	9	 For we are but of yesterday, and know nothing, because our days upon earth are a shadow--
13040	18	8	10	 Shall not they teach thee, and tell thee, and utter words out of their heart?
13041	18	8	11	 Can the rush shoot up without mire? Can the reed-grass grow without water?
13042	18	8	12	 Whilst it is yet in its greenness, and not cut down, it withereth before any other herb.
13043	18	8	13	 So are the paths of all that forget God; and the hope of the godless man shall perish;
13044	18	8	14	 Whose confidence is gossamer, and whose trust is a spider's web.
13045	18	8	15	 He shall lean upon his house, but it shall not stand; he shall hold fast thereby, but it shall not endure.
13046	18	8	16	 He is green before the sun, and his shoots go forth over his garden.
13047	18	8	17	 His roots are wrapped about the heap, he beholdeth the place of stones.
13048	18	8	18	 If he be destroyed from his place, then it shall deny him: 'I have not seen thee.'
13049	18	8	19	 Behold, this is the joy of his way, and out of the earth shall others spring.
13050	18	8	20	 Behold, God will not cast away an innocent man, neither will He uphold the evil-doers;
13051	18	8	21	 Till He fill thy mouth with laughter, and thy lips with shouting.
13052	18	8	22	 They that hate thee shall be clothed with shame; and the tent of the wicked shall be no more.
13053	18	9	1	 Then Job answered and said:
13054	18	9	2	 Of a truth I know that it is so; and how can man be just with God?
13055	18	9	3	 If one should desire to contend with Him, he could not answer Him one of a thousand.
13056	18	9	4	 He is wise in heart, and mighty in strength; who hath hardened himself against Him, and prospered?
13057	18	9	5	 Who removeth the mountains, and they know it not, when He overturneth them in His anger.
13058	18	9	6	 Who shaketh the earth out of her place, and the pillars thereof tremble.
13059	18	9	7	 Who commandeth the sun, and it riseth not; and sealeth up the stars.
13060	18	9	8	 Who alone stretcheth out the heavens, and treadeth upon the waves of the sea.
13061	18	9	9	 Who maketh the Bear, Orion, and the Pleiades, and the chambers of the south.
13062	18	9	10	 Who doeth great things past finding out; yea, marvellous things without number.
13063	18	9	11	 Lo, He goeth by me, and I see Him not. He passeth on also, but I perceive Him not.
13064	18	9	12	 Behold, He snatcheth away, who can hinder Him? Who will say unto Him: 'What doest Thou?'
13065	18	9	13	 God will not withdraw His anger; the helpers of Rahab did stoop under Him.
13066	18	9	14	 How much less shall I answer Him, and choose out my arguments with Him?
13067	18	9	15	 Whom, though I were righteous, yet would I not answer; I would make supplication to Him that contendeth with me.
13068	18	9	16	 If I had called, and He had answered me; yet would I not believe that He would hearken unto my voice--
13069	18	9	17	 He that would break me with a tempest, and multiply my wounds without cause;
13070	18	9	18	 That would not suffer me to take my breath, but fill me with bitterness.
13071	18	9	19	 If it be a matter of strength, lo, He is mighty! and if of justice, who will appoint me a time?
13072	18	9	20	 Though I be righteous, mine own mouth shall condemn me; though I be innocent, He shall prove me perverse.
13073	18	9	21	 I am innocent--I regard not myself, I despise my life.
13074	18	9	22	 It is all one--therefore I say: He destroyeth the innocent and the wicked.
13075	18	9	23	 If the scourge slay suddenly, He will mock at the calamity of the guiltless.
13076	18	9	24	 The earth is given into the hand of the wicked; he covereth the faces of the judges thereof; if it be not He, who then is it?
13077	18	9	25	 Now my days are swifter than a runner; they flee away, they see no good.
13078	18	9	26	 They are passed away as the swift ships; as the vulture that swoopeth on the prey.
13079	18	9	27	 If I say: 'I will forget my complaint, I will put off my sad countenance, and be of good cheer',
13080	18	9	28	 I am afraid of all my pains, I know that Thou wilt not hold me guiltless.
13081	18	9	29	 I shall be condemned; why then do I labour in vain?
13082	18	9	30	 If I wash myself with snow water, and make my hands never so clean;
13083	18	9	31	 Yet wilt Thou plunge me in the ditch, and mine own clothes shall abhor me.
13084	18	9	32	 For He is not a man, as I am, that I should answer Him, that we should come together in judgment.
13085	18	9	33	 There is no arbiter betwixt us, that might lay his hand upon us both.
13086	18	9	34	 Let Him take His rod away from me, and let not His terror make me afraid;
13087	18	9	35	 Then would I speak, and not fear Him; for I am not so with myself.
13088	18	10	1	 My soul is weary of my life; I will give free course to my complaint; I will speak in the bitterness of my soul.
13089	18	10	2	 I will say unto God: Do not condemn me; make me know wherefore Thou contendest with me.
13090	18	10	3	 Is it good unto Thee that Thou shouldest oppress, that Thou shouldest despise the work of Thy hands, and shine upon the counsel of the wicked?
13091	18	10	4	 Hast Thou eyes of flesh? or seest Thou as man seeth?
13092	18	10	5	 Are Thy days as the days of man, or Thy years as a man's days,
13093	18	10	6	 That Thou inquirest after mine iniquity, and searchest after my sin,
13094	18	10	7	 Although Thou knowest that I shall not be condemned; and there is none that can deliver out of Thy hand?
13095	18	10	8	 Thy hands have framed me and fashioned me together round about; yet Thou dost destroy me!
13096	18	10	9	 Remember, I beseech Thee, that Thou hast fashioned me as clay; and wilt Thou bring me into dust again?
13097	18	10	10	 Hast Thou not poured me out as milk, and curdled me like cheese?
13098	18	10	11	 Thou hast clothed me with skin and flesh, and knit me together with bones and sinews.
13099	18	10	12	 Thou hast granted me life and favour, and Thy providence hath preserved my spirit.
13100	18	10	13	 Yet these things Thou didst hide in Thy heart; I know that this is with Thee;
13101	18	10	14	 If I sin, then Thou markest me, and Thou wilt not acquit me from mine iniquity.
13102	18	10	15	 If I be wicked, woe unto me; and if I be righteous, yet shall I not lift up my head--being filled with ignominy and looking upon mine affliction.
13103	18	10	16	 And if it exalt itself, Thou huntest me as a lion; and again Thou showest Thyself marvellous upon me.
13104	18	10	17	 Thou renewest Thy witnesses against me, and increasest Thine indignation upon me; host succeeding host against me.
13105	18	10	18	 Wherefore then hast Thou brought me forth out of the womb? Would that I had perished, and no eye had seen me!
13106	18	10	19	 I should have been as though I had not been; I should have been carried from the womb to the grave.
13107	18	10	20	 Are not my days few? Cease then, and let me alone, that I may take comfort a little,
13108	18	10	21	 Before I go whence I shall not return, even to the land of darkness and of the shadow of death;
13109	18	10	22	 A land of thick darkness, as darkness itself; a land of the shadow of death, without any order, and where the light is as darkness.
13110	18	11	1	 Then answered Zophar the Naamathite, and said:
13111	18	11	2	 Should not the multitude of words be answered? And should a man full of talk be accounted right?
13112	18	11	3	 Thy boastings have made men hold their peace, and thou hast mocked, with none to make thee ashamed;
13113	18	11	4	 And thou hast said: 'My doctrine is pure, and I am clean in Thine eyes.'
13114	18	11	5	 But oh that God would speak, and open His lips against thee;
13115	18	11	6	 And that He would tell thee the secrets of wisdom, that sound wisdom is manifold! Know therefore that God exacteth of thee less than thine iniquity deserveth.
13116	18	11	7	 Canst thou find out the deep things of God? Canst thou attain unto the purpose of the Almighty?
13117	18	11	8	 It is high as heaven; what canst thou do? Deeper than the nether-world; what canst thou know?
13118	18	11	9	 The measure thereof is longer than the earth, and broader than the sea.
13119	18	11	10	 If He pass by, and shut up, or gather in, then who can hinder Him?
13120	18	11	11	 For He knoweth base men; and when He seeth iniquity, will He not then consider it?
13121	18	11	12	 But an empty man will get understanding, when a wild ass's colt is born a man.
13122	18	11	13	 If thou set thy heart aright, and stretch out thy hands toward Him--

13124	18	11	15	 Surely then shalt thou lift up thy face without spot; yea, thou shalt be stedfast, and shalt not fear;
13125	18	11	16	 For thou shalt forget thy misery; thou shalt remember it as waters that are passed away;
13126	18	11	17	 And thy life shall be clearer than the noonday; though there be darkness, it shall be as the morning.
13127	18	11	18	 And thou shalt be secure, because there is hope; yea, thou shalt look about thee, and shalt take thy rest in safety.
13128	18	11	19	 Also thou shalt lie down, and none shall make thee afraid; yea, many shall make suit unto thee.
13129	18	11	20	 But the eyes of the wicked shall fail, and they shall have no way to flee, and their hope shall be the drooping of the soul.
13130	18	12	1	 Then Job answered and said:
13131	18	12	2	 No doubt but ye are the people, and wisdom shall die with you.
13132	18	12	3	 But I have understanding as well as you; I am not inferior to you; yea, who knoweth not such things as these?
13133	18	12	4	 I am as one that is a laughing-stock to his neighbour, a man that called upon God, and He answered him; the just, the innocent man is a laughing-stock,
13134	18	12	5	 A contemptible brand in the thought of him that is at ease, a thing ready for them whose foot slippeth.
13135	18	12	6	 The tents of robbers prosper, and they that provoke God are secure, in whatsoever God bringeth into their hand.
13136	18	12	7	 But ask now the beasts, and they shall teach thee; and the fowls of the air, and they shall tell thee;
13137	18	12	8	 Or speak to the earth, and it shall teach thee; and the fishes of the sea shall declare unto thee;
13138	18	12	9	 Who knoweth not among all these, that the hand of the LORD hath wrought this?
13139	18	12	10	 In whose hand is the soul of every living thing, and the breath of all mankind.--
13140	18	12	11	 Doth not the ear try words, even as the palate tasteth its food?
13141	18	12	12	 Is wisdom with aged men, and understanding in length of days?--
13142	18	12	13	 With Him is wisdom and might; He hath counsel and understanding.
13143	18	12	14	 Behold, He breaketh down, and it cannot be built again; He shutteth up a man, and there can be no opening.
13144	18	12	15	 Behold, He withholdeth the waters, and they dry up; also He sendeth them out, and they overturn the earth.
13145	18	12	16	 With Him is strength and sound wisdom; the deceived and the deceiver are His.
13146	18	12	17	 He leadeth counsellors away stripped, and judges maketh He fools.

13148	18	12	19	 He leadeth priests away stripped, and overthroweth the mighty.

13151	18	12	22	 He uncovereth deep things out of darkness, and bringeth out to light the shadow of death.
13152	18	12	23	 He increaseth the nations, and destroyeth them; He enlargeth the nations, and leadeth them away.

13154	18	12	25	 They grope in the dark without light, and He maketh them to stagger like a drunken man.
13155	18	13	1	 Lo, mine eye hath seen all this, mine ear hath heard and understood it.
13156	18	13	2	 What ye know, do I know also; I am not inferior unto you.
13157	18	13	3	 Notwithstanding I would speak to the Almighty, and I desire to reason with God.
13158	18	13	4	 But ye are plasterers of lies, ye are all physicians of no value.
13159	18	13	5	 Oh that ye would altogether hold your peace! and it would be your wisdom.
13160	18	13	6	 Hear now my reasoning, and hearken to the pleadings of my lips.
13161	18	13	7	 Will ye speak unrighteously for God, and talk deceitfully for Him?
13162	18	13	8	 Will ye show Him favour? Will ye contend for God?
13163	18	13	9	 Would it be good that He should search you out? Or as one mocketh a man, will ye mock Him?
13164	18	13	10	 He will surely reprove you, if ye do secretly show favour.
13165	18	13	11	 Shall not His majesty terrify you, and His dread fall upon you?
13166	18	13	12	 Your memorials shall be like unto ashes, your eminences to eminences of clay.
13167	18	13	13	 Hold your peace, let me alone, that I may speak, and let come on me what will.
13168	18	13	14	 Wherefore? I will take my flesh in my teeth, and put my life in my hand.

13170	18	13	16	 This also shall be my salvation, that a hypocrite cannot come before Him.
13171	18	13	17	 Hear diligently my speech, and let my declaration be in your ears.
13172	18	13	18	 Behold now, I have ordered my cause; I know that I shall be justified.

13175	18	13	21	 Withdraw Thy hand far from me; and let not Thy terror make me afraid.

13178	18	13	24	 Wherefore hidest Thou Thy face, and holdest me for Thine enemy?
13179	18	13	25	 Wilt Thou harass a driven leaf? And wilt Thou pursue the dry stubble?

13182	18	13	28	 Though I am like a wine-skin that consumeth, like a garment that is moth-eaten.
13183	18	14	1	 Man that is born of a woman is of few days, and full of trouble.
13184	18	14	2	 He cometh forth like a flower, and withereth; he fleeth also as a shadow, and continueth not.
13185	18	14	3	 And dost Thou open Thine eyes upon such a one, and bringest me into judgment with Thee?
13186	18	14	4	 Who can bring a clean thing out of an unclean? not one.
13187	18	14	5	 Seeing his days are determined, the number of his months is with Thee, and Thou hast appointed his bounds that he cannot pass;
13188	18	14	6	 Look away from him, that he may rest, till he shall accomplish, as a hireling, his day.
13189	18	14	7	 For there is hope of a tree, if it be cut down, that it will sprout again, and that the tender branch thereof will not cease.
13190	18	14	8	 Though the root thereof wax old in the earth, and the stock thereof die in the ground;
13191	18	14	9	 Yet through the scent of water it will bud, and put forth boughs like a plant.
13192	18	14	10	 But man dieth, and lieth low; yea, man perisheth, and where is he?
13193	18	14	11	 As the waters fail from the sea, and the river is drained dry;
13194	18	14	12	 So man lieth down and riseth not; till the heavens be no more, they shall not awake, nor be roused out of their sleep.

13197	18	14	15	 Thou wouldest call, and I would answer Thee; Thou wouldest have a desire to the work of Thy hands.

13199	18	14	17	 My transgression is sealed up in a bag, and Thou heapest up mine iniquity.

13201	18	14	19	 The waters wear the stones; the overflowings thereof wash away the dust of the earth; so Thou destroyest the hope of man.
13202	18	14	20	 Thou prevailest for ever against him, and he passeth; Thou changest his countenance, and sendest him away.
