13204	18	14	22	 But his flesh grieveth for him, and his soul mourneth over him.
13205	18	15	1	 Then answered Eliphaz the Temanite, and said:
13206	18	15	2	 Should a wise man make answer with windy knowledge, and fill his belly with the east wind?
13207	18	15	3	 Should he reason with unprofitable talk, or with speeches wherewith he can do no good?
13208	18	15	4	 Yea, thou doest away with fear, and impairest devotion before God.
13209	18	15	5	 For thine iniquity teacheth thy mouth, and thou choosest the tongue of the crafty.
13210	18	15	6	 Thine own mouth condemneth thee, and not I; yea, thine own lips testify against thee.
13211	18	15	7	 Art thou the first man that was born? Or wast thou brought forth before the hills?
13212	18	15	8	 Dost thou hearken in the council of God? And dost thou restrain wisdom to thyself?
13213	18	15	9	 What knowest thou, that we know not? What understandest thou, which is not in us?
13214	18	15	10	 With us are both the gray-headed and the very aged men, much older than thy father.
13215	18	15	11	 Are the consolations of God too small for thee, and the word that dealeth gently with thee?
13216	18	15	12	 Why doth thy heart carry thee away? And why do thine eyes wink?
13217	18	15	13	 That thou turnest thy spirit against God, and lettest such words go out of thy mouth.
13218	18	15	14	 What is man, that he should be clean? And he that is born of a woman, that he should be righteous?
13219	18	15	15	 Behold, He putteth no trust in His holy ones; yea, the heavens are not clean in His sight.
13220	18	15	16	 How much less one that is abominable and impure, man who drinketh iniquity like water!
13221	18	15	17	 I will tell thee, hear thou me; and that which I have seen I will declare--
13222	18	15	18	 Which wise men have told from their fathers, and have not hid it;
13223	18	15	19	 Unto whom alone the land was given, and no stranger passed among them.
13224	18	15	20	 The wicked man travaileth with pain all his days, even the number of years that are laid up for the oppressor.
13225	18	15	21	 A sound of terrors is in his ears: in prosperity the destroyer shall come upon him.
13226	18	15	22	 He believeth not that he shall return out of darkness, and he is waited for of the sword.
13227	18	15	23	 He wandereth abroad for bread: 'Where is it?' He knoweth that the day of darkness is ready at his hand.
13228	18	15	24	 Distress and anguish overwhelm him; they prevail against him, as a king ready to the battle.
13229	18	15	25	 Because he hath stretched out his hand against God, and behaveth himself proudly against the Almighty;
13230	18	15	26	 He runneth upon him with a stiff neck, with the thick bosses of his bucklers.
13231	18	15	27	 Because he hath covered his face with his fatness, and made collops of fat on his loins;
13232	18	15	28	 And he hath dwelt in desolate cities, in houses which no man would inhabit, which were ready to become heaps.
13233	18	15	29	 He shall not be rich, neither shall his substance continue, neither shall their produce bend to the earth.
13234	18	15	30	 He shall not depart out of darkness; the flame shall dry up his branches, and by the breath of His mouth shall he go away.
13235	18	15	31	 Let him not trust in vanity, deceiving himself; for vanity shall be his recompense.
13236	18	15	32	 It shall be accomplished before his time, and his branch shall not be leafy.
13237	18	15	33	 He shall shake off his unripe grape as the vine, and shall cast off his flower as the olive.
13238	18	15	34	 For the company of the godless shall be desolate, and fire shall consume the tents of bribery.
13239	18	15	35	 They conceive mischief, and bring forth iniquity, and their belly prepareth deceit.
13240	18	16	1	 Then Job answered and said:
13241	18	16	2	 I have heard many such things; sorry comforters are ye all.
13242	18	16	3	 Shall windy words have an end? Or what provoketh thee that thou answerest?
13243	18	16	4	 I also could speak as ye do; if your soul were in my soul's stead, I could join words together against you, and shake my head at you.
13244	18	16	5	 I would strengthen you with my mouth, and the moving of my lips would assuage your grief.
13245	18	16	6	 Though I speak, my pain is not assuaged; and though I forbear, what am I eased?
13246	18	16	7	 But now He hath made me weary; Thou hast made desolate all my company.
13247	18	16	8	 And Thou hast shrivelled me up, which is a witness against me; and my leanness riseth up against me, it testifieth to my face.
13248	18	16	9	 He hath torn me in His wrath, and hated me; He hath gnashed upon me with His teeth; mine adversary sharpeneth his eyes upon me.
13249	18	16	10	 They have gaped upon me with their mouth; they have smitten me upon the cheek scornfully; they gather themselves together against me.
13250	18	16	11	 God delivereth me to the ungodly, and casteth me into the hands of the wicked.
13251	18	16	12	 I was at ease, and He broke me asunder; yea, He hath taken me by the neck, and dashed me to pieces; He hath also set me up for His mark.
13252	18	16	13	 His archers compass me round about, He cleaveth my reins asunder, and doth not spare; He poureth out my gall upon the ground.
13253	18	16	14	 He breaketh me with breach upon breach; He runneth upon me like a giant.
13254	18	16	15	 I have sewed sackcloth upon my skin, and have laid my horn in the dust.
13255	18	16	16	 My face is reddened with weeping, and on my eyelids is the shadow of death;
13256	18	16	17	 Although there is no violence in my hands, and my prayer is pure.
13257	18	16	18	 O earth, cover not thou my blood, and let my cry have no resting-place.
13258	18	16	19	 Even now, behold, my Witness is in heaven, and He that testifieth of me is on high.
13259	18	16	20	 Mine inward thoughts are my intercessors, mine eye poureth out tears unto God;
13260	18	16	21	 That He would set aright a man contending with God, as a son of man setteth aright his neighbour!
13261	18	16	22	 For the years that are few are coming on, and I shall go the way whence I shall not return.
13262	18	17	1	 My spirit is consumed, my days are extinct, the grave is ready for me.
13263	18	17	2	 Surely there are mockers with me, and mine eye abideth in their provocation.
13264	18	17	3	 Give now a pledge, be surety for me with Thyself; who else is there that will strike hands with me?
13265	18	17	4	 For Thou hast hid their heart from understanding; therefore shalt Thou not exalt them.
13266	18	17	5	 He that denounceth his friends for the sake of flattery, even the eyes of his children shall fail.
13267	18	17	6	 He hath made me also a byword of the people; and I am become one in whose face they spit.
13268	18	17	7	 Mine eye also is dimmed by reason of vexation, and all my members are as a shadow.
13269	18	17	8	 Upright men are astonished at this, and the innocent stirreth up himself against the godless.
13270	18	17	9	 Yet the righteous holdeth on his way, and he that hath clean hands waxeth stronger and stronger.
13271	18	17	10	 But as for you all, do ye return, and come now; and I shall not find a wise man among you.
13272	18	17	11	 My days are past, my purposes are broken off, even the thoughts of my heart.
13273	18	17	12	 They change the night into day; the light is short because of darkness.
13274	18	17	13	 If I look for the nether-world as my house; if I have spread my couch in the darkness;
13275	18	17	14	 If I have said to corruption: 'Thou art my father', to the worm: 'Thou art my mother, and my sister';
13276	18	17	15	 Where then is my hope? And as for my hope, who shall see it?
13277	18	17	16	 They shall go down to the bars of the nether-world, when we are at rest together in the dust.
13278	18	18	1	 Then answered Bildad the Shuhite, and said:
13279	18	18	2	 How long will ye lay snares for words? Consider, and afterwards we will speak.
13280	18	18	3	 Wherefore are we counted as beasts, and reputed dull in your sight?
13281	18	18	4	 Thou that tearest thyself in thine anger, shall the earth be forsaken for thee? Or shall the rock be removed out of its place?
13282	18	18	5	 Yea, the light of the wicked shall be put out, and the spark of his fire shall not shine.
13283	18	18	6	 The light shall be dark in his tent, and his lamp over him shall be put out.
13284	18	18	7	 The steps of his strength shall be straitened, and his own counsel shall cast him down.
13285	18	18	8	 For he is cast into a net by his own feet, and he walketh upon the toils.
13286	18	18	9	 A gin shall take him by the heel, and a snare shall lay hold on him.
13287	18	18	10	 A noose is hid for him in the ground, and a trap for him in the way.
13288	18	18	11	 Terrors shall overwhelm him on every side, and shall entrap him at his feet.
13289	18	18	12	 His trouble shall be ravenous, and calamity shall be ready for his fall.
13290	18	18	13	 It shall devour the members of his body, yea, the first-born of death shall devour his members.
13291	18	18	14	 That wherein he trusteth shall be plucked out of his tent; and he shall be brought to the king of terrors.
13292	18	18	15	 There shall dwell in his tent that which is none of his; brimstone shall be scattered upon his habitation.
13293	18	18	16	 His roots shall dry up beneath, and above shall his branch wither.
13294	18	18	17	 His remembrance shall perish from the earth, and he shall have no name abroad.
13295	18	18	18	 He shall be driven from light into darkness, and chased out of the world.
13296	18	18	19	 He shall have neither son nor son's son among his people, nor any remaining in his dwellings.
13297	18	18	20	 They that come after shall be astonished at his day, as they that went before are affrighted.
13298	18	18	21	 Surely such are the dwellings of the wicked, and this is the place of him that knoweth not God.
13299	18	19	1	 Then Job answered and said:
13300	18	19	2	 How long will ye vex my soul, and crush me with words?
13301	18	19	3	 These ten times have ye reproached me; ye are not ashamed that ye deal harshly with me.
13302	18	19	4	 And be it indeed that I have erred, mine error remaineth with myself.
13303	18	19	5	 If indeed ye will magnify yourselves against me, and plead against me my reproach;
13304	18	19	6	 Know now that God hath subverted my cause, and hath compassed me with His net.
13305	18	19	7	 Behold, I cry out: 'Violence!' but I am not heard; I cry aloud, but there is no justice.
13306	18	19	8	 He hath fenced up my way that I cannot pass, and hath set darkness in my paths.
13307	18	19	9	 He hath stripped me of my glory, and taken the crown from my head.
13308	18	19	10	 He hath broken me down on every side, and I am gone; and my hope hath He plucked up like a tree.
13309	18	19	11	 He hath also kindled His wrath against me, and He counteth me unto Him as one of His adversaries.
13310	18	19	12	 His troops come on together, and cast up their way against me, and encamp round about my tent.
13311	18	19	13	 He hath put my brethren far from me, and mine acquaintance are wholly estranged from me.
13312	18	19	14	 My kinsfolk have failed, and my familiar friends have forgotten me.
13313	18	19	15	 They that dwell in my house, and my maids, count me for a stranger; I am become an alien in their sight.
13314	18	19	16	 I call unto my servant, and he giveth me no answer, though I entreat him with my mouth.
13315	18	19	17	 My breath is abhorred of my wife, and I am loathsome to the children of my tribe.
13316	18	19	18	 Even urchins despised me; if I arise, they speak against me.
13317	18	19	19	 All my intimate friends abhor me; and they whom I loved are turned against me.
13318	18	19	20	 My bone cleaveth to my skin and to my flesh, and I am escaped with the skin of my teeth.
13319	18	19	21	 Have pity upon me, have pity upon me, O ye my friends; for the hand of God hath touched me.
13320	18	19	22	 Why do ye persecute me as God, and are not satisfied with my flesh?
13321	18	19	23	 Oh that my words were now written! Oh that they were inscribed in a book!
13322	18	19	24	 That with an iron pen and lead they were graven in the rock for ever!
13323	18	19	25	 But as for me, I know that my Redeemer liveth, and that He will witness at the last upon the dust;
13324	18	19	26	 And when after my skin this is destroyed, then without my flesh shall I see God;
13325	18	19	27	 Whom I, even I, shall see for myself, and mine eyes shall behold, and not another's. My reins are consumed within me.
13326	18	19	28	 If ye say: 'How we will persecute him!' seeing that the root of the matter is found in me;
13327	18	19	29	 Be ye afraid of the sword; for wrath bringeth the punishments of the sword, that ye may know there is a judgment.
13328	18	20	1	 Then answered Zophar the Naamathite, and said:
13329	18	20	2	 Therefore do my thoughts give answer to me, even by reason of mine agitation that is in me.
13330	18	20	3	 I have heard the reproof which putteth me to shame, but out of my understanding my spirit answereth me.
13331	18	20	4	 Knowest thou not this of old time, since man was placed upon earth,
13332	18	20	5	 That the triumphing of the wicked is short, and the joy of the godless but for a moment?
13333	18	20	6	 Though his excellency mount up to the heavens, and his head reach unto the clouds;
13334	18	20	7	 Yet he shall perish for ever like his own dung; they that have seen him shall say: 'Where is he?'
13335	18	20	8	 He shall fly away as a dream, and shall not be found; yea, he shall be chased away as a vision of the night.
13336	18	20	9	 The eye which saw him shall see him no more; neither shall his place any more behold him.
13337	18	20	10	 His children shall appease the poor, and his hands shall restore his wealth.
13338	18	20	11	 His bones are full of his youth, but it shall lie down with him in the dust.
13339	18	20	12	 Though wickedness be sweet in his mouth, though he hide it under his tongue;
13340	18	20	13	 Though he spare it, and will not let it go, but keep it still within his mouth;
13341	18	20	14	 Yet his food in his bowels is turned, it is the gall of asps within him.
13342	18	20	15	 He hath swallowed down riches, and he shall vomit them up again; God shall cast them out of his belly.
13343	18	20	16	 He shall suck the poison of asps; the viper's tongue shall slay him.
13344	18	20	17	 He shall not look upon the rivers, the flowing streams of honey and curd.
13345	18	20	18	 That which he laboured for shall he give back, and shall not swallow it down; according to the substance that he hath gotten, he shall not rejoice.
13346	18	20	19	 For he hath oppressed and forsaken the poor; he hath violently taken away a house, and he shall not build it up.
13347	18	20	20	 Because he knew no quietness within him, in his greed he suffered nought to escape,
13348	18	20	21	 There was nothing left that he devoured not--therefore his prosperity shall not endure.
13349	18	20	22	 In the fulness of his sufficiency he shall be in straits; the hand of every one that is in misery shall come upon him.
13350	18	20	23	 It shall be for the filling of his belly; He shall cast the fierceness of His wrath upon him, and shall cause it to rain upon him into his flesh.
13351	18	20	24	 If he flee from the iron weapon, the bow of brass shall strike him through.
13352	18	20	25	 He draweth it forth, and it cometh out of his body; yea, the glittering point cometh out of his gall; terrors are upon him.
13353	18	20	26	 All darkness is laid up for his treasures; a fire not blown by man shall consume him; it shall go ill with him that is left in his tent.
13354	18	20	27	 The heavens shall reveal his iniquity, and the earth shall rise up against him.
13355	18	20	28	 The increase of his house shall depart, his goods shall flow away in the day of his wrath.
13356	18	20	29	 This is the portion of a wicked man from God, and the heritage appointed unto him by God.
13357	18	21	1	 Then Job answered and said:
13358	18	21	2	 Hear diligently my speech; and let this be your consolations.
13359	18	21	3	 Suffer me, that I may speak; and after that I have spoken, mock on.
13360	18	21	4	 As for me, is my complaint to man? Or why should I not be impatient?
13361	18	21	5	 Turn unto me, and be astonished, and lay your hand upon your mouth.
13362	18	21	6	 Even when I remember I am affrighted, and horror hath taketh hold on my flesh.
13363	18	21	7	 Wherefore do the wicked live, become old, yea, wax mighty in power?
13364	18	21	8	 Their seed is established in their sight with them, and their offspring before their eyes.
13365	18	21	9	 Their houses are safe, without fear, neither is the rod of God upon them.
13366	18	21	10	 Their bull gendereth, and faileth not; their cow calveth, and casteth not her calf.
13367	18	21	11	 They send forth their little ones like a flock, and their children dance.
13368	18	21	12	 They sing to the timbrel and harp, and rejoice at the sound of the pipe.
13369	18	21	13	 They spend their days in prosperity, and peacefully they go down to the grave.
13370	18	21	14	 Yet they said unto God: 'Depart from us; for we desire not the knowledge of Thy ways.
13371	18	21	15	 What is the Almighty, that we should serve Him? And what profit should we have, if we pray unto Him?'--
13372	18	21	16	 Lo, their prosperity is not in their hand; the counsel of the wicked is far from me.
13373	18	21	17	 How oft is it that the lamp of the wicked is put out? that their calamity cometh upon them? that He distributeth pains in His anger?
13374	18	21	18	 That they are as stubble before the wind, and as chaff that the storm stealeth away?
13375	18	21	19	 'God layeth up his iniquity for his children!' --let Him recompense it unto himself, that he may know it.
13376	18	21	20	 Let his own eyes see his destruction, and let him drink of the wrath of the Almighty.
13377	18	21	21	 For what pleasure hath he in his house after him? seeing the number of his months is determined.
13378	18	21	22	 Shall any teach God knowledge? seeing it is He that judgeth those that are high.
13379	18	21	23	 One dieth in his full strength, being wholly at ease and quiet;
13380	18	21	24	 His pails are full of milk, and the marrow of his bones is moistened.
13381	18	21	25	 And another dieth in bitterness of soul, and hath never tasted of good.
13382	18	21	26	 They lie down alike in the dust, and the worm covereth them.
13383	18	21	27	 Behold, I know your thoughts, and the devices which ye wrongfully imagine against me.
13384	18	21	28	 For ye say: 'Where is the house of the prince? And where is the tent wherein the wicked dwelt?'
13385	18	21	29	 Have ye not asked them that go by the way; and will ye misdeem their tokens,
13386	18	21	30	 That the evil man is reserved to the day of calamity, that they are led forth to the day of wrath?
13387	18	21	31	 But who shall declare his way to his face? And who shall repay him what he hath done?
13388	18	21	32	 For he is borne to the grave, and watch is kept over his tomb.
13389	18	21	33	 The clods of the valley are sweet unto him, and all men draw after him, as there were innumerable before him.
13390	18	21	34	 How then comfort ye me in vain? And as for your answers, there remaineth only faithlessness?
13391	18	22	1	 Then answered Eliphaz the Temanite, and said:
13392	18	22	2	 Can a man be profitable unto God? Or can he that is wise be profitable unto Him?
13393	18	22	3	 Is it any advantage to the Almighty, that thou art righteous? Or is it gain to Him, that thou makest thy ways blameless?
13394	18	22	4	 Is it for thy fear of Him that He reproveth thee, that He entereth with thee into judgment?
13395	18	22	5	 Is not thy wickedness great? And are not thine iniquities without end?
13396	18	22	6	 For thou hast taken pledges of thy brother for nought, and stripped the naked of their clothing.
13397	18	22	7	 Thou hast not given water to the weary to drink, and thou hast withholden bread from the hungry.
13398	18	22	8	 And as a mighty man, who hath the earth, and as a man of rank, who dwelleth in it,
13399	18	22	9	 Thou hast sent widows away empty, and the arms of the fatherless have been broken.
13400	18	22	10	 Therefore snares are round about thee, and sudden dread affrighted thee,
13401	18	22	11	 Or darkness, that thou canst not see, and abundance of waters cover thee.
13402	18	22	12	 Is not God in the height of heaven? And behold the topmost of the stars, how high they are!
13403	18	22	13	 And thou sayest: 'What doth God know? Can He judge through the dark cloud?
13404	18	22	14	 Thick clouds are a covering to Him, that He seeth not; and He walketh in the circuit of heaven.'
13405	18	22	15	 Wilt thou keep the old way which wicked men have trodden?
13406	18	22	16	 Who were snatched away before their time, whose foundation was poured out as a stream;
13407	18	22	17	 Who said unto God: 'Depart from us'; and what could the Almighty do unto them?
13408	18	22	18	 Yet He filled their houses with good things--but the counsel of the wicked is far from me.
13409	18	22	19	 The righteous saw it, and were glad, and the innocent laugh them to scorn:
13410	18	22	20	 'Surely their substance is cut off, and their abundance the fire hath consumed.'
13411	18	22	21	 Acquaint now thyself with Him, and be at peace; thereby shall thine increase be good.
13412	18	22	22	 Receive, I pray thee, instruction from His mouth, and lay up His words in thy heart.
13413	18	22	23	 If thou return to the Almighty, thou shalt be built up--if thou put away unrighteousness far from thy tents,
13414	18	22	24	 And lay thy treasure in the dust, and the gold of Ophir among the stones of the brooks;
13415	18	22	25	 And the Almighty be thy treasure, and precious silver unto thee;
13416	18	22	26	 Then surely shalt thou have thy delight in the Almighty, and shalt lift up thy face unto God.
13417	18	22	27	 Thou shalt make thy prayer unto Him, and He will hear thee, and thou shalt pay thy vows;
13418	18	22	28	 Thou shalt also decree a thing, and it shall be established unto thee, and light shall shine upon thy ways.
13419	18	22	29	 When they cast thee down, thou shalt say: 'There is lifting up'; for the humble person He saveth.
13420	18	22	30	 He delivereth him that is innocent, yea, thou shalt be delivered through the cleanness of thy hands.
13421	18	23	1	 Then Job answered and said:
13422	18	23	2	 Even to-day is my complaint bitter; my hand is become heavy because of my groaning.
13423	18	23	3	 Oh that I knew where I might find Him, that I might come even to His seat!
13424	18	23	4	 I would order my cause before Him, and fill my mouth with arguments.
13425	18	23	5	 I would know the words which He would answer me, and understand what He would say unto me.
13426	18	23	6	 Would He contend with me in His great power? Nay; but He would give heed unto me.
13427	18	23	7	 There the upright might reason with Him; so should I be delivered for ever from my Judge.
13428	18	23	8	 Behold, I go forward, but He is not there, and backward, but I cannot perceive Him;
13429	18	23	9	 On the left hand, when He doth work, but I cannot behold Him, He turneth Himself to the right hand, but I cannot see Him.
13430	18	23	10	 For He knoweth the way that I take; when He hath tried me, I shall come forth as gold.
13431	18	23	11	 My foot hath held fast to His steps, His way have I kept, and turned not aside.
13432	18	23	12	 I have not gone back from the commandment of His lips; I have treasured up the words of His mouth more than my necessary food.
13433	18	23	13	 But He is at one with Himself, and who can turn Him? And what His soul desireth, even that He doeth.
13434	18	23	14	 For He will perform that which is appointed for me; and many such things are with Him.
13435	18	23	15	 Therefore am I affrighted at His presence; when I consider, I am afraid of Him.
13436	18	23	16	 Yea, God hath made my heart faint, and the Almighty hath affrighted me;
13437	18	23	17	 Because I was not cut off before the darkness, neither did He cover the thick darkness from my face.
13438	18	24	1	 Why are times not laid up by the Almighty? And why do not they that know Him see His days?
13439	18	24	2	 There are that remove the landmarks; they violently take away flocks, and feed them.
13440	18	24	3	 They drive away the ass of the fatherless, they take the widow's ox for a pledge.
13441	18	24	4	 They turn the needy out of the way; the poor of the earth hide themselves together.
13442	18	24	5	 Behold, as wild asses in the wilderness they go forth to their work, seeking diligently for food; the desert yieldeth them bread for their children.
13443	18	24	6	 They cut his provender in the field; and they despoil the vineyard of the wicked.
13444	18	24	7	 They lie all night naked without clothing, and have no covering in the cold.
13445	18	24	8	 They are wet with the showers of the mountains, and embrace the rock for want of a shelter.
13446	18	24	9	 There are that pluck the fatherless from the breast, and take a pledge of the poor;
13447	18	24	10	 So that they go about naked without clothing, and being hungry they carry the sheaves;
13448	18	24	11	 They make oil within the rows of these men; they tread their winepresses, and suffer thirst.
13449	18	24	12	 From out of the populous city men groan, and the soul of the wounded crieth out; yet God imputeth it not for unseemliness.
13450	18	24	13	 These are of them that rebel against the light; they know not the ways thereof, nor abide in the paths thereof.
13451	18	24	14	 The murderer riseth with the light, to kill the poor and needy; and in the night he is as a thief.
13452	18	24	15	 The eye also of the adulterer waiteth for the twilight, saying: 'No eye shall see me'; and he putteth a covering on his face.
13453	18	24	16	 In the dark they dig through houses; they shut themselves up in the day-time; they know not the light.
13454	18	24	17	 For the shadow of death is to all of them as the morning; for they know the terrors of the shadow of death.
13455	18	24	18	 He is swift upon the face of the waters; their portion is cursed in the earth; he turneth not by the way of the vineyards.
13456	18	24	19	 Drought and heat consume the snow waters; so doth the nether-world those that have sinned.
13457	18	24	20	 The womb forgetteth him; the worm feedeth sweetly on him; he shall be no more remembered; and unrighteousness is broken as a tree.
13458	18	24	21	 He devoureth the barren that beareth not; and doeth not good to the widow.
13459	18	24	22	 He draweth away the mighty also by his power; he riseth up, and he trusteth not his own life.
13460	18	24	23	 Though it be given him to be in safety, whereon he resteth, yet His eyes are upon their ways.
13461	18	24	24	 They are exalted for a little while, and they are gone; yea, they are brought low, they are gathered in as all others, and wither as the tops of the ears of corn.
13462	18	24	25	 And if it be not so now, who will prove me a liar, and make my speech nothing worth?
13463	18	25	1	 Then answered Bildad the Shuhite, and said:
13464	18	25	2	 Dominion and fear are with Him; He maketh peace in His high places.
13465	18	25	3	 Is there any number of His armies? And upon whom doth not His light arise?
13466	18	25	4	 How then can man be just with God? Or how can he be clean that is born of a woman?
13467	18	25	5	 Behold, even the moon hath no brightness, and the stars are not pure in His sight;
13468	18	25	6	 How much less man, that is a worm! and the son of man, that is a maggot!
13469	18	26	1	 Then Job answered and said:
13470	18	26	2	 How hast thou helped him that is without power! How hast thou saved the arm that hath no strength!
13471	18	26	3	 How hast thou counselled him that hath no wisdom, and plentifully declared sound knowledge!
13472	18	26	4	 With whose help hast thou uttered words? And whose spirit came forth from thee?
13473	18	26	5	 The shades tremble beneath the waters and the inhabitants thereof.
13474	18	26	6	 The nether-world is naked before Him, and Destruction hath no covering.
13475	18	26	7	 He stretcheth out the north over the empty space, and hangeth the earth over nothing.
13476	18	26	8	 He bindeth up the waters in His thick clouds; and the cloud is not rent under them.
13477	18	26	9	 He closeth in the face of His throne, and spreadeth His cloud upon it.
13478	18	26	10	 He hath described a boundary upon the face of the waters, unto the confines of light and darkness.
13479	18	26	11	 The pillars of heaven tremble and are astonished at His rebuke.
13480	18	26	12	 He stirreth up the sea with His power, and by His understanding He smiteth through Rahab.
13481	18	26	13	 By His breath the heavens are serene; His hand hath pierced the slant serpent.
13482	18	26	14	 Lo, these are but the outskirts of His ways; and how small a whisper is heard of Him! But the thunder of His mighty deeds who can understand?
13483	18	27	1	 And Job again took up his parable, and said:
13484	18	27	2	 As God liveth, who hath taken away my right; and the Almighty, who hath dealt bitterly with me;
13485	18	27	3	 All the while my breath is in me, and the spirit of God is in my nostrils,
13486	18	27	4	 Surely my lips shall not speak unrighteousness, neither shall my tongue utter deceit;
13487	18	27	5	 Far be it from me that I should justify you; till I die I will not put away mine integrity from me.
13488	18	27	6	 My righteousness I hold fast, and will not let it go; my heart shall not reproach me so long as I live.
13489	18	27	7	 Let mine enemy be as the wicked, and let him that riseth up against me be as the unrighteous.
13490	18	27	8	 For what is the hope of the godless, though he get him gain, when God taketh away his soul?
13491	18	27	9	 Will God hear his cry, when trouble cometh upon him?
13492	18	27	10	 Will he have his delight in the Almighty, and call upon God at all times?
13493	18	27	11	 I will teach you concerning the hand of God; that which is with the Almighty will I not conceal.
13494	18	27	12	 Behold, all ye yourselves have seen it; why then are ye become altogether vain?
13495	18	27	13	 This is the portion of a wicked man with God, and the heritage of oppressors, which they receive from the Almighty.
13496	18	27	14	 If his children be multiplied, it is for the sword; and his offspring shall not have bread enough.
13497	18	27	15	 Those that remain of him shall be buried by pestilence, and his widows shall make no lamentation.
13498	18	27	16	 Though he heap up silver as the dust, and prepare raiment as the clay;
13499	18	27	17	 He may prepare it, but the just shall put it on, and the innocent shall divide the silver.
13500	18	27	18	 He buildeth his house as a moth, and as a booth which the keeper maketh.
13501	18	27	19	 He lieth down rich, but there shall be not to gather; he openeth his eyes, and his wealth is not.
13502	18	27	20	 Terrors overtake him like waters; a tempest stealeth him away in the night.
13503	18	27	21	 The east wind carrieth him away, and he departeth; and it sweepeth him out of his place.
13504	18	27	22	 Yea, it hurleth at him, and spareth not; he would fain flee from its power.
13505	18	27	23	 Men shall clap their hands at him, and shall hiss him out of his place.
13506	18	28	1	 For there is a mine for silver, and a place for gold which they refine.
13507	18	28	2	 Iron is taken out of the dust, and brass is molten out of the stone.
13508	18	28	3	 Man setteth an end to darkness, and searcheth out to the furthest bound the stones of thick darkness and of the shadow of death.
13509	18	28	4	 He breaketh open a shaft away from where men sojourn; they are forgotten of the foot that passeth by; they hang afar from men, they swing to and fro.
13510	18	28	5	 As for the earth, out of it cometh bread, and underneath it is turned up as it were by fire.
13511	18	28	6	 The stones thereof are the place of sapphires, and it hath dust of gold.
13512	18	28	7	 That path no bird of prey knoweth, neither hath the falcon's eye seen it;
13513	18	28	8	 The proud beasts have not trodden it, nor hath the lion passed thereby.
13514	18	28	9	 He putteth forth his hand upon the flinty rock; He overturneth the mountains by the roots.
13515	18	28	10	 He cutteth out channels among the rocks; and his eye seeth every precious thing.
13516	18	28	11	 He bindeth the streams that they trickle not; and the thing that is hid bringeth he forth to light.
13517	18	28	12	 But wisdom, where shall it be found? And where is the place of understanding?
13518	18	28	13	 Man knoweth not the price thereof; neither is it found in the land of the living.
13519	18	28	14	 The deep saith: 'It is not in me'; and the sea saith: 'It is not with me.'
13520	18	28	15	 It cannot be gotten for gold, neither shall silver be weighed for the price thereof.
13521	18	28	16	 It cannot be valued with the gold of Ophir, with the precious onyx, or the sapphire.
13522	18	28	17	 Gold and glass cannot equal it; neither shall the exchange thereof be vessels of fine gold.
13523	18	28	18	 No mention shall be made of coral or of crystal; yea, the price of wisdom is above rubies.
13524	18	28	19	 The topaz of Ethiopia shall not equal it, neither shall it be valued with pure gold.
13525	18	28	20	 Whence then cometh wisdom? And where is the place of understanding?
13526	18	28	21	 Seeing it is hid from the eyes of all living, and kept close from the fowls of the air.
13527	18	28	22	 Destruction and Death say: 'We have heard a rumor thereof with our ears.'
13528	18	28	23	 God understandeth the way thereof, and He knoweth the place thereof.
13529	18	28	24	 For He looketh to the ends of the earth, and seeth under the whole heaven;
13530	18	28	25	 When He maketh a weight for the wind, and meteth out the waters by measure.
13531	18	28	26	 When He made a decree for the rain, and a way for the storm of thunders;
13532	18	28	27	 Then did He see it, and declare it; He established it, yea, and searched it out.
13533	18	28	28	 And unto man He said: 'Behold, the fear of the Lord, that is wisdom; and to depart from evil is understanding.'
13534	18	29	1	 And Job again took up his parable, and said:
13535	18	29	2	 Oh that I were as in the months of old, as in the days when God watched over me;
13536	18	29	3	 When His lamp shined above my head, and by His light I walked through darkness;
13537	18	29	4	 As I was in the days of my youth, when the converse of God was upon my tent;
13538	18	29	5	 When the Almighty was yet with me, and my children were about me;
13539	18	29	6	 When my steps were washed with butter, and the rock poured me out rivers of oil!
13540	18	29	7	 When I went forth to the gate unto the city, when I prepared my seat in the broad place,
13541	18	29	8	 The young men saw me and hid themselves, and the aged rose up and stood;
13542	18	29	9	 The princes refrained talking, and laid their hand on their mouth;
13543	18	29	10	 The voice of the nobles was hushed, and their tongue cleaved to the roof of their mouth.
13544	18	29	11	 For when the ear heard me, then it blessed me, and when the eye saw me, it gave witness unto me;
13545	18	29	12	 Because I delivered the poor that cried, the fatherless also, that had none to help him.
13546	18	29	13	 The blessing of him that was ready to perish came upon me; and I caused the widow's heart to sing for joy.
13547	18	29	14	 I put on righteousness, and it clothed itself with me; my justice was as a robe and a diadem.
13548	18	29	15	 I was eyes to the blind, and feet was I to the lame.
13549	18	29	16	 I was a father to the needy; and the cause of him that I knew not I searched out.
13550	18	29	17	 And I broke the jaws of the unrighteous, and plucked the prey out of his teeth.
13551	18	29	18	 Then I said: 'I shall die with my nest, and I shall multiply my days as the phoenix;
13552	18	29	19	 My root shall be spread out to the waters, and the dew shall lie all night upon my branch;
13553	18	29	20	 My glory shall be fresh in me, and my bow shall be renewed in my hand.'
13554	18	29	21	 Unto me men gave ear, and waited, and kept silence for my counsel.
13555	18	29	22	 After my words they spoke not again; and my speech dropped upon them.
13556	18	29	23	 And they waited for me as for the rain; and they opened their mouth wide as for the latter rain.
13557	18	29	24	 If I laughed on them, they believed it not; and the light of my countenance they cast not down.
13558	18	29	25	 I chose out their way, and sat as chief, and dwelt as a king in the army, as one that comforteth the mourners.
13559	18	30	1	 But now they that are younger than I have me in derision, whose fathers I disdained to set with the dogs of my flock.
13560	18	30	2	 Yea, the strength of their hands, whereto should it profit me? men in whom ripe age is perished.
13561	18	30	3	 They are gaunt with want and famine; they gnaw the dry ground, in the gloom of wasteness and desolation.
13562	18	30	4	 They pluck salt-wort with wormwood; and the roots of the broom are their food.
13563	18	30	5	 They are driven forth from the midst of men; they cry after them as after a thief.
13564	18	30	6	 In the clefts of the valleys must they dwell, in holes of the earth and of the rocks.
13565	18	30	7	 Among the bushes they bray; under the nettles they are gathered together.
13566	18	30	8	 They are children of churls, yea, children of ignoble men; they were scourged out of the land.
13567	18	30	9	 And now I am become their song, yea, I am a byword unto them.
13568	18	30	10	 They abhor me, they flee far from me, and spare not to spit in my face.
13569	18	30	11	 For He hath loosed my cord, and afflicted me, and they have cast off the bridle before me.
13570	18	30	12	 Upon my right hand rise the brood; they entangle my feet, and they cast up against me their ways of destruction.
13571	18	30	13	 They break up my path, they further my calamity, even men that have no helper.
13572	18	30	14	 As through a wide breach they come; in the midst of the ruin they roll themselves upon me.
13573	18	30	15	 Terrors are turned upon me, they chase mine honour as the wind; and my welfare is passed away as a cloud.
13574	18	30	16	 And now my soul is poured out within me; days of affliction have taken hold upon me.
13575	18	30	17	 In the night my bones are pierced, and fall from me, and my sinews take no rest.
13576	18	30	18	 By the great force of my disease is my garment disfigured; it bindeth me about as the collar of my coat.
13577	18	30	19	 He hath cast me into the mire, and I am become like dust and ashes.
13578	18	30	20	 I cry unto Thee, and Thou dost not answer me; I stand up, and Thou lookest at me.
13579	18	30	21	 Thou art turned to be cruel to me; with the might of Thy hand Thou hatest me.
13580	18	30	22	 Thou liftest me up to the wind, Thou causest me to ride upon it; and Thou dissolvest my substance.
13581	18	30	23	 For I know that Thou wilt bring me to death, and to the house appointed for all living.
13582	18	30	24	 Surely none shall put forth his hand to a ruinous heap, neither because of these things shall help come in one's calamity,
13583	18	30	25	 If I have not wept for him that was in trouble, and if my soul grieved not for the needy.
13584	18	30	26	 Yet, when I looked for good, there came evil; and when I waited for light, there came darkness.
13585	18	30	27	 Mine inwards boil, and rest not; days of affliction are come upon me.
13586	18	30	28	 I go mourning without the sun; I stand up in the assembly, and cry for help.
13587	18	30	29	 I am become a brother to jackals, and a companion to ostriches.
13588	18	30	30	 My skin is black, and falleth from me, and my bones are burned with heat.
13589	18	30	31	 Therefore is my harp turned to mourning, and my pipe into the voice of them that weep.
13590	18	31	1	 I made a covenant with mine eyes; how then should I look upon a maid?
13591	18	31	2	 For what would be the portion of God from above, and the heritage of the Almighty from on high?
13592	18	31	3	 Is it not calamity to the unrighteous, and disaster to the workers of iniquity?
13593	18	31	4	 Doth not He see my ways, and count all my steps?
13594	18	31	5	 If I have walked with vanity, and my foot hath hasted to deceit--
13595	18	31	6	 Let me be weighed in a just balance, that God may know mine integrity--
13596	18	31	7	 If my step hath turned out of the way, and my heart walked after mine eyes, and if any spot hath cleaved to my hands;
13597	18	31	8	 Then let me sow, and let another eat; yea, let the produce of my field be rooted out.
13598	18	31	9	 If my heart have been enticed unto a woman, and I have lain in wait at my neighbour's door;
13599	18	31	10	 Then let my wife grind unto another, and let others bow down upon her.
13600	18	31	11	 For that were a heinous crime; yea, it were an iniquity to be punished by the judges.
13601	18	31	12	 For it is a fire that consumeth unto destruction, and would root out all mine increase.
13602	18	31	13	 If I did despise the cause of my man-servant, or of my maid-servant, when they contended with me--
13603	18	31	14	 What then shall I do when God riseth up? And when He remembereth, what shall I answer Him?
13604	18	31	15	 Did not He that made me in the womb make him? And did not One fashion us in the womb?
13605	18	31	16	 If I have withheld aught that the poor desired, or have caused the eyes of the widow to fail;
13606	18	31	17	 Or have eaten my morsel myself alone, and the fatherless hath not eaten thereof--
13607	18	31	18	 Nay, from my youth he grew up with me as with a father, and I have been her guide from my mother's womb.
13608	18	31	19	 If I have seen any wanderer in want of clothing, or that the needy had no covering;
13609	18	31	20	 If his loins have not blessed me, and if he were not warmed with the fleece of my sheep;
13610	18	31	21	 If I have lifted up my hand against the fatherless, because I saw my help in the gate;
13611	18	31	22	 Then let my shoulder fall from the shoulder-blade, and mine arm be broken from the bone.
13612	18	31	23	 For calamity from God was a terror to me, and by reason of His majesty I could do nothing.
13613	18	31	24	 If I have made gold my hope, and have said to the fine gold: 'Thou art my confidence';
13614	18	31	25	 If I rejoiced because my wealth was great, and because my hand had gotten much;
13615	18	31	26	 If I beheld the sun when it shined, or the moon walking in brightness;
13616	18	31	27	 And my heart hath been secretly enticed, and my mouth hath kissed my hand;
13617	18	31	28	 This also were an iniquity to be punished by the judges; for I should have lied to God that is above.
13618	18	31	29	 If I rejoiced at the destruction of him that hated me, or exulted when evil found him--
13619	18	31	30	 Yea, I suffered not my mouth to sin by asking his life with a curse.
13620	18	31	31	 If the men of my tent said not: 'Who can find one that hath not been satisfied with his meat?'
13621	18	31	32	 The stranger did not lodge in the street; my doors I opened to the roadside.
13622	18	31	33	 If after the manner of men I covered my transgressions, by hiding mine iniquity in my bosom--
13623	18	31	34	 Because I feared the great multitude, and the most contemptible among families terrified me, so that I kept silence, and went not out of the door.
13624	18	31	35	 Oh that I had one to hear me! --Lo, here is my signature, let the Almighty answer me--and that I had the indictment which mine adversary hath written!
13625	18	31	36	 Surely I would carry it upon my shoulder; I would bind it unto me as a crown.
13626	18	31	37	 I would declare unto him the number of my steps; as a prince would I go near unto him.
13627	18	31	38	 If my land cry out against me, and the furrows thereof weep together;
13628	18	31	39	 If I have eaten the fruits thereof without money, or have caused the tillers thereof to be disappointed--
13629	18	31	40	 Let thistles grow instead of wheat, and noisome weeds instead of barley. The words of Job are ended.
13630	18	32	1	 So these three men ceased to answer Job, because he was righteous in his own eyes.
13631	18	32	2	 Then was kindled the wrath of Elihu the son of Barachel the Buzite, of the family of Ram; against Job was his wrath kindled, because he justified himself rather than God.
13632	18	32	3	 Also against his three friends was his wrath kindled, because they had found no answer, and yet had condemned Job.
13633	18	32	4	 Now Elihu had waited to speak unto Job, because they were older than he.
13634	18	32	5	 And when Elihu saw that there was no answer in the mouth of these three men, his wrath was kindled.
13635	18	32	6	 And Elihu the son of Barachel the Buzite answered and said: I am young, and ye are very old; wherefore I held back, and durst not declare you mine opinion.
13636	18	32	7	 I said: 'Days should speak, and multitude of years should teach wisdom.'
13637	18	32	8	 But it is a spirit in man, and the breath of the Almighty, that giveth them understanding.
13638	18	32	9	 It is not the great that are wise, nor the aged that discern judgment.
13639	18	32	10	 Therefore I say: 'Hearken to me; I also will declare mine opinion.'
13640	18	32	11	 Behold, I waited for your words, I listened for your reasons, whilst ye searched out what to say.
13641	18	32	12	 Yea, I attended unto you, and, behold, there was none that convinced Job, or that answered his words, among you.
13642	18	32	13	 Beware lest ye say: 'We have found wisdom; God may vanquish him, not man!'
13643	18	32	14	 For he hath not directed his words against me; neither will I answer him with your speeches.
13644	18	32	15	 They are amazed, they answer no more; words are departed from them.
13645	18	32	16	 And shall I wait, because they speak not, because they stand still, and answer no more?
13646	18	32	17	 I also will answer my part, I also will declare mine opinion.
13647	18	32	18	 For I am full of words; the spirit within me constraineth me.
13648	18	32	19	 Behold, mine inwards are as wine which hath no vent; like new wine-skins which are ready to burst.
13649	18	32	20	 I will speak, that I may find relief; I will open my lips and answer.
13650	18	32	21	 Let me not, I pray you, respect any man's person; neither will I give flattering titles unto any man.
13651	18	32	22	 For I know not to give flattering titles; else would my Maker soon take me away.
13652	18	33	1	 Howbeit, Job, I pray thee, hear my speech, and hearken to all my words.
13653	18	33	2	 Behold now, I have opened my mouth, my tongue hath spoken in my mouth.
13654	18	33	3	 My words shall utter the uprightness of my heart; and that which my lips know they shall speak sincerely.
13655	18	33	4	 The spirit of God hath made me, and the breath of the Almighty given me life.
13656	18	33	5	 If thou canst, answer thou me, set thy words in order before me, stand forth.
13657	18	33	6	 Behold, I am toward God even as thou art; I also am formed out of the clay.
13658	18	33	7	 Behold, my terror shall not make thee afraid, neither shall my pressure be heavy upon thee.
13659	18	33	8	 Surely thou hast spoken in my hearing, and I have heard the voice of thy words;
13660	18	33	9	 'I am clean, without transgression, I am innocent, neither is there iniquity in me;
13661	18	33	10	 Behold, He findeth occasions against me, He counteth me for His enemy;
13662	18	33	11	 He putteth my feet in the stocks, He marketh all my paths.'
13663	18	33	12	 Behold, I answer thee: In this thou art not right, that God is too great for man;
13664	18	33	13	 Why hast thou striven against Him? seeing that He will not answer any of his words.
13665	18	33	14	 For God speaketh in one way, yea in two, though man perceiveth it not.
13666	18	33	15	 In a dream, in a vision of the night, when deep sleep falleth upon men, in slumberings upon the bed;
13667	18	33	16	 Then He openeth the ears of men, and by their chastisement sealeth the decree,
13668	18	33	17	 That men may put away their purpose, and that He may hide pride from man;
13669	18	33	18	 That He may keep back his soul from the pit, and his life from perishing by the sword.
13670	18	33	19	 He is chastened also with pain upon his bed, and all his bones grow stiff;
13671	18	33	20	 So that his life maketh him to abhor bread, and his soul dainty food.
13672	18	33	21	 His flesh is consumed away, that it cannot be seen; and his bones corrode to unsightliness.
13673	18	33	22	 Yea, his soul draweth near unto the pit, and his life to the destroyers.
13674	18	33	23	 If there be for him an angel, an intercessor, one among a thousand, to vouch for a man's uprightness;
13675	18	33	24	 Then He is gracious unto him, and saith: 'Deliver him from going down to the pit, I have found a ransom.'
13676	18	33	25	 His flesh is tenderer than a child's; he returneth to the days of his youth;
13677	18	33	26	 He prayeth unto God, and He is favourable unto him; so that he seeth His face with joy; and He restoreth unto man his righteousness.
13678	18	33	27	 He cometh before men, and saith: 'I have sinned, and perverted that which was right, and it profited me not.'
13679	18	33	28	 So He redeemeth his soul from going into the pit, and his life beholdeth the light.
13680	18	33	29	 Lo, all these things doth God work, twice, yea thrice, with a man,
13681	18	33	30	 To bring back his soul from the pit, that he may be enlightened with the light of the living.
13682	18	33	31	 Mark well, O Job, hearken unto me; hold thy peace, and I will speak.
13683	18	33	32	 If thou hast any thing to say, answer me; speak, for I desire to justify thee.
13684	18	33	33	 If not, hearken thou unto me; hold thy peace, and I will teach thee wisdom.
13685	18	34	1	 Moreover Elihu answered and said:
13686	18	34	2	 Hear my words, ye wise men; and give ear unto me, ye that have knowledge.
13687	18	34	3	 For the ear trieth words, as the palate tasteth food.
13688	18	34	4	 Let us choose for us that which is right; let us know among ourselves what is good.
13689	18	34	5	 For Job hath said: 'I am righteous, and God hath taken away my right;
13690	18	34	6	 Notwithstanding my right I am accounted a liar; my wound is incurable, though I am without transgression.'
13691	18	34	7	 What man is like Job, who drinketh up scorning like water?
13692	18	34	8	 Who goeth in company with the workers of iniquity, and walketh with wicked men.
13693	18	34	9	 For he hath said: 'It profiteth a man nothing that he should be in accord with God.'
13694	18	34	10	 Therefore hearken unto me, ye men of understanding: Far be it from God, that He should do wickedness; and from the Almighty, that He should commit iniquity.
13695	18	34	11	 For the work of a man will He requite unto him, and cause every man to find according to his ways.
13696	18	34	12	 Yea, of a surety, God will not do wickedly, neither will the Almighty pervert justice.
13697	18	34	13	 Who gave Him a charge over the earth? Or who hath disposed the whole world?
13698	18	34	14	 If He set His heart upon man, if He gather unto Himself his spirit and his breath;
13699	18	34	15	 All flesh shall perish together, and man shall return unto dust.
13700	18	34	16	 If now thou hast understanding, hear this; hearken to the voice of my words.
13701	18	34	17	 Shall even one that hateth right govern? And wilt thou condemn Him that is just and mighty--
13702	18	34	18	 Is it fit to say to a king: 'Thou art base'? Or to nobles: 'Ye are wicked'?--
13703	18	34	19	 That respecteth not the persons of princes, nor regardeth the rich more than the poor? For they all are the work of His hands.
13704	18	34	20	 In a moment they die, even at midnight; the people are shaken and pass away, and the mighty are taken away without hand.
13705	18	34	21	 For His eyes are upon the ways of a man, and He seeth all his goings.
13706	18	34	22	 There is no darkness, nor shadow of death, where the workers of iniquity may hide themselves.
13707	18	34	23	 For He doth not appoint a time unto any man, when he should go before God in judgment.
13708	18	34	24	 He breaketh in pieces mighty men without inquisition, and setteth others in their stead.
13709	18	34	25	 Therefore He taketh knowledge of their works; and He overturneth them in the night, so that they are crushed.
13710	18	34	26	 He striketh them as wicked men in the open sight of others;
13711	18	34	27	 Because they turned aside from following Him, and would not have regard to any of His ways;
13712	18	34	28	 So that they cause the cry of the poor to come unto Him, and He heareth the cry of the afflicted.
13713	18	34	29	 When He giveth quietness, who then can condemn? And when He hideth His face, who then can behold Him? whether it be done unto a nation, or unto a man, alike;
13714	18	34	30	 That the godless man reign not, that there be none to ensnare the people.
13715	18	34	31	 For hath any said unto God: 'I have borne chastisement, though I offend not;
13716	18	34	32	 That which I see not teach Thou me; if I have done iniquity, I will do it no more'?
13717	18	34	33	 Shall His recompense be as thou wilt? For thou loathest it, so that thou must choose, and not I; therefore speak what thou knowest.
13718	18	34	34	 Men of understanding will say unto me, yea, every wise man that heareth me:
13719	18	34	35	 'Job speaketh without knowledge, and his words are without discernment.'
13720	18	34	36	 Would that Job were tried unto the end, because of his answering like wicked men.
13721	18	34	37	 For he addeth rebellion unto his sin, he clappeth his hands among us, and multiplieth his words against God.
13722	18	35	1	 Moreover Elihu answered and said:
13723	18	35	2	 Thinkest thou this to be thy right, or sayest thou: 'I am righteousness before God',
13724	18	35	3	 That thou inquirest: 'What advantage will it be unto Thee?' And: 'What profit shall I have, more than if I had sinned?'
13725	18	35	4	 I will give thee answer, and thy companions with thee.
13726	18	35	5	 Look unto the heavens, and see; and behold the skies, which are higher than thou.
13727	18	35	6	 If thou hast sinned, what doest thou against Him? And if thy transgressions be multiplied, what doest thou unto Him?
13728	18	35	7	 If thou be righteous, what givest thou Him? Or what receiveth He of thy hand?
13729	18	35	8	 Thy wickedness concerneth a man as thou art; and thy righteousness a son of man.
13730	18	35	9	 By reason of the multitude of oppressions they cry out; they cry for help by reason of the arm of the mighty.
13731	18	35	10	 But none saith: 'Where is God my Maker, who giveth songs in the night;
13732	18	35	11	 Who teacheth us more than the beasts of the earth, and maketh us wiser than the fowls of heaven?'
13733	18	35	12	 There they cry, but none giveth answer, because of the pride of evil men.
13734	18	35	13	 Surely God will not hear vanity, neither will the Almighty regard it.
13735	18	35	14	 Yea, when thou sayest thou canst not see Him--the cause is before Him; therefore wait thou for Him.
13736	18	35	15	 And now, is it for nought that He punished in His anger? And hath He not full knowledge of arrogance?
13737	18	35	16	 But Job doth open his mouth in vanity; he multiplieth words without knowledge.
13738	18	36	1	 Elihu also proceeded, and said:
13739	18	36	2	 Suffer me a little, and I will tell thee; for there are yet words on God's behalf.
13740	18	36	3	 I will fetch my knowledge from afar, and will ascribe righteousness to my Maker.
13741	18	36	4	 For truly my words are not false; one that is upright in mind is with thee.
13742	18	36	5	 Behold, God is mighty, yet He despiseth not any; He is mighty in strength of understanding.
13743	18	36	6	 He preserveth not the life of the wicked; but giveth to the poor their right.
13744	18	36	7	 He withdraweth not His eyes from the righteous; but with kings upon the throne He setteth them for ever, and they are exalted.
13745	18	36	8	 And if they be bound in fetters, and be holden in cords of affliction;
13746	18	36	9	 Then He declareth unto them their work, and their transgressions, that they have behaved themselves proudly.
13747	18	36	10	 He openeth also their ear to discipline, and commandeth that they return from iniquity.
13748	18	36	11	 If they hearken and serve Him, they shall spend their days in prosperity, and their years in pleasures.
13749	18	36	12	 But if they hearken not, they shall perish by the sword, and they shall die without knowledge.
13750	18	36	13	 But they that are godless in heart lay up anger; they cry not for help when He bindeth them.
13751	18	36	14	 Their soul perisheth in youth, and their life as that of the depraved.
13752	18	36	15	 He delivereth the afflicted by His affliction, and openeth their ear by tribulation.
13753	18	36	16	 Yea, He hath allured thee out of distress into a broad place, where there is no straitness; and that which is set on thy table is full of fatness;
13754	18	36	17	 And thou art full of the judgment of the wicked; judgment and justice take hold on them.
13755	18	36	18	 For beware of wrath, lest thou be led away by thy sufficiency; neither let the greatness of the ransom turn thee aside.
13756	18	36	19	 Will thy riches avail, that are without stint, or all the forces of thy strength?
13757	18	36	20	 Desire not the night, when peoples are cut off in their place.
13758	18	36	21	 Take heed, regard not iniquity; for this hast thou chosen rather than affliction.
13759	18	36	22	 Behold, God doeth loftily in His power; who is a teacher like Him?
13760	18	36	23	 Who hath enjoined Him His way? Or who hath said: 'Thou hast wrought unrighteousness'?
13761	18	36	24	 Remember that thou magnify His work, whereof men have sung.
13762	18	36	25	 All men have looked thereon; man beholdeth it afar off.
13763	18	36	26	 Behold, God is great, beyond our knowledge; the number of His years is unsearchable.
13764	18	36	27	 For He draweth away the drops of water, which distil rain from His vapour;
13765	18	36	28	 Which the skies pour down and drop upon the multitudes of men.
13766	18	36	29	 Yea, can any understand the spreadings of the clouds, the crashings of His pavilion?
13767	18	36	30	 Behold, He spreadeth His light upon it; and He covereth the depths of the sea.
13768	18	36	31	 For by these He judgeth the peoples; He giveth food in abundance.
13769	18	36	32	 He covereth His hands with the lightning, and giveth it a charge that it strike the mark.
13770	18	36	33	 The noise thereof telleth concerning it, the cattle also concerning the storm that cometh up.
13771	18	37	1	 At this also my heart trembleth, and is moved out of its place.
13772	18	37	2	 Hear attentively the noise of His voice, and the sound that goeth out of His mouth.
13773	18	37	3	 He sendeth it forth under the whole heaven, and His lightning unto the ends of the earth.
13774	18	37	4	 After it a voice roareth; He thundereth with the voice of His majesty; and He stayeth them not when His voice is heard.
13775	18	37	5	 God thundereth marvellously with His voice; great things doeth He, which we cannot comprehend.
13776	18	37	6	 For He saith to the snow: 'Fall thou on the earth'; likewise to the shower of rain, and to the showers of His mighty rain.
13777	18	37	7	 He sealeth up the hand of every man, that all men whom He hath made may know it.
13778	18	37	8	 Then the beasts go into coverts, and remain in their dens.
13779	18	37	9	 Out of the Chamber cometh the storm; and cold out of the north.
13780	18	37	10	 By the breath of God ice is given, and the breadth of the waters is straitened.
13781	18	37	11	 Yea, He ladeth the thick cloud with moister, He spreadeth abroad the cloud of His lightning;
13782	18	37	12	 And they are turned round about by His guidance, that they may do whatsoever He commandeth them upon the face of the habitable world:
13783	18	37	13	 Whether it be for correction, or for His earth, or for mercy, that He cause it to come.
13784	18	37	14	 Hearken unto this, O Job; Stand still, and consider the wondrous works of God.
13785	18	37	15	 Dost thou know how God enjoineth them, and causeth the lightning of His cloud to shine?
13786	18	37	16	 Dost thou know the balancings of the clouds, the wondrous works of Him who is perfect in knowledge?
13787	18	37	17	 Thou whose garments are warm, when the earth is still by reason of the south wind;
13788	18	37	18	 Canst thou with Him spread out the sky, which is strong as a molten mirror?
13789	18	37	19	 Teach us what we shall say unto Him; for we cannot order our speech by reason of darkness.
13790	18	37	20	 Shall it be told Him that I would speak? Or should a man wish that he were swallowed up?
13791	18	37	21	 And now men see not the light which is bright in the skies; but the wind passeth, and cleanseth them.
13792	18	37	22	 Out of the north cometh golden splendour, about God is terrible majesty.
13793	18	37	23	 The Almighty, whom we cannot find out, is excellent in power, yet to judgment and plenteous justice He doeth no violence.
13794	18	37	24	 Men do therefore fear Him; He regardeth not any that are wise of heart.
13795	18	38	1	 Then the LORD answered Job out of the whirlwind, and said:
13796	18	38	2	 Who is this that darkeneth counsel by words without knowledge?
13797	18	38	3	 Gird up now thy loins like a man; for I will demand of thee, and declare thou unto Me.
13798	18	38	4	 Where wast thou when I laid the foundations of the earth? Declare, if thou hast the understanding.
13799	18	38	5	 Who determined the measures thereof, if thou knowest? Or who stretched the line upon it?
13800	18	38	6	 Whereupon were the foundations thereof fastened? Or who laid the corner-stone thereof,
13801	18	38	7	 When the morning stars sang together, and all the sons of God shouted for joy?
13802	18	38	8	 Or who shut up the sea with doors, when it broke forth, and issued out of the womb;
13803	18	38	9	 When I made the cloud the garment thereof, and thick darkness a swaddlingband for it,
13804	18	38	10	 And prescribed for it My decree, and set bars and doors,
13805	18	38	11	 And said: 'Thus far shalt thou come, but no further; and here shall thy proud waves be stayed'?
13806	18	38	12	 Hast thou commanded the morning since thy days began, and caused the dayspring to know its place;
13807	18	38	13	 That it might take hold of the ends of the earth, and the wicked be shaken out of it?
13808	18	38	14	 It is changed as clay under the seal; and they stand as a garment.
13809	18	38	15	 But from the wicked their light is withholden, and the high arm is broken.
13810	18	38	16	 Hast thou entered into the springs of the sea? Or hast thou walked in the recesses of the deep?
13811	18	38	17	 Have the gates of death been revealed unto thee? Or hast thou seen the gates of the shadow of death?
13812	18	38	18	 Hast thou surveyed unto the breadths of the earth? Declare, if thou knowest it all.
13813	18	38	19	 Where is the way to the dwelling of light, and as for darkness, where is the place thereof;
13814	18	38	20	 That thou shouldest take it to the bound thereof, and that thou shouldest know the paths to the house thereof?
13815	18	38	21	 Thou knowest it, for thou wast then born, and the number of thy days is great!
13816	18	38	22	 Hast thou entered the treasuries of the snow, or hast thou seen the treasuries of the hail,
13817	18	38	23	 Which I have reserved against the time of trouble, against the day of battle and war?
13818	18	38	24	 By what way is the light parted, or the east wind scattered upon the earth?
13819	18	38	25	 Who hath cleft a channel for the waterflood, or a way for the lightning of the thunder;
13820	18	38	26	 To cause it to rain on a land where no man is, on the wilderness, wherein there is no man;
13821	18	38	27	 To satisfy the desolate and waste ground, and to cause the bud of the tender herb to spring forth?
13822	18	38	28	 Hath the rain a father? Or who hath begotten the drops of dew?
13823	18	38	29	 Out of whose womb came the ice? And the hoar-frost of heaven, who hath gendered it?
13824	18	38	30	 The waters are congealed like stone, and the face of the deep is frozen.
13825	18	38	31	 Canst thou bind the chains of the Pleiades, or loose the bands of Orion?
13826	18	38	32	 Canst thou lead forth the Mazzaroth in their season? Or canst thou guide the Bear with her sons?
13827	18	38	33	 Knowest thou the ordinances of the heavens? Canst thou establish the dominion thereof in the earth?
13828	18	38	34	 Canst thou lift up thy voice to the clouds, that abundance of waters may cover thee?
13829	18	38	35	 Canst thou send forth lightnings, that they may go, and say unto thee: 'Here we are'?
13830	18	38	36	 Who hath put wisdom in the inward parts? Or who hath given understanding to the mind?
13831	18	38	37	 Who can number the clouds by wisdom? Or who can pour out the bottles of heaven,
13832	18	38	38	 When the dust runneth into a mass, and the clods cleave fast together?
13833	18	38	39	 Wilt thou hunt the prey for the lioness? Or satisfy the appetite of the young lions,
13834	18	38	40	 When they couch in their dens, and abide in the covert to lie in wait?
13835	18	38	41	 Who provideth for the raven his prey, when his young ones cry unto God, and wander for lack of food?
13836	18	39	1	 Knowest thou the time when the wild goats of the rock bring forth? Or canst thou mark when the hinds do calve?
13837	18	39	2	 Canst thou number the months that they fulfil? Or knowest thou the time when they bring forth?
13838	18	39	3	 They bow themselves, they bring forth their young, they cast out their fruit.
13839	18	39	4	 Their young ones wax strong, they grow up in the open field; they go forth, and return not again.
13840	18	39	5	 Who hath sent out the wild ass free? Or who hath loosed the bands of the wild ass?
13841	18	39	6	 Whose house I have made the wilderness, and the salt land his dwelling-place.
13842	18	39	7	 He scorneth the tumult of the city, neither heareth he the shoutings of the driver.
13843	18	39	8	 The range of the mountains is his pasture, and he searcheth after every green thing.
13844	18	39	9	 Will the wild-ox be willing to serve thee? Or will he abide by thy crib?
13845	18	39	10	 Canst thou bind the wild-ox with his band in the furrow? Or will he harrow the valleys after thee?
13846	18	39	11	 Wilt thou trust him, because his strength is great? Or wilt thou leave thy labour to him?
13847	18	39	12	 Wilt thou rely on him, that he will bring home thy seed, and gather the corn of thy threshing-floor?
13848	18	39	13	 The wing of the ostrich beateth joyously; but are her pinions and feathers the kindly stork's?
13849	18	39	14	 For she leaveth her eggs on the earth, and warmeth them in dust,
13850	18	39	15	 And forgetteth that the foot may crush them, or that the wild beast may trample them.
13851	18	39	16	 She is hardened against her young ones, as if they were not hers; though her labour be in vain, she is without fear;
13852	18	39	17	 Because God hath deprived her of wisdom, neither hath He imparted to her understanding.
13853	18	39	18	 When the time cometh, she raiseth her wings on high, and scorneth the horse and his rider.
13854	18	39	19	 Hast thou given the horse his strength? Hast thou clothed his neck with fierceness?
13855	18	39	20	 Hast thou made him to leap as a locust? The glory of his snorting is terrible.
13856	18	39	21	 He paweth in the valley, and rejoiceth in his strength; he goeth out to meet the clash of arms.
13857	18	39	22	 He mocketh at fear, and is not affrighted; neither turneth he back from the sword.
13858	18	39	23	 The quiver rattleth upon him, the glittering spear and the javelin.
13859	18	39	24	 He swalloweth the ground with storm and rage; neither believeth he that it is the voice of the horn.
13860	18	39	25	 As oft as he heareth the horn he saith: 'Ha, ha!' and he smelleth the battle afar off, the thunder of the captains, and the shouting.
13861	18	39	26	 Doth the hawk soar by thy wisdom, and stretch her wings toward the south?
13862	18	39	27	 Doth the vulture mount up at thy command, and make her nest on high?
13863	18	39	28	 She dwelleth and abideth on the rock, upon the crag of the rock, and the stronghold.
13864	18	39	29	 From thence she spieth out the prey; her eyes behold it afar off.
13865	18	39	30	 Her young ones also suck up blood; and where the slain are, there is she.
13866	18	40	1	 Moreover the LORD answered Job, and said:
13867	18	40	2	 Shall he that reproveth contend with the Almighty? He that argueth with God, let him answer it.
13868	18	40	3	 Then Job answered the LORD, and said:
13869	18	40	4	 Behold, I am of small account; what shall I answer Thee? I lay my hand upon my mouth.
13870	18	40	5	 Once have I spoken, but I will not answer again; yea, twice, but I will proceed no further.
13871	18	40	6	 Then the LORD answered Job out of the whirlwind, and said:
13872	18	40	7	 Gird up thy loins now like a man; I will demand of thee, and declare thou unto Me.
13873	18	40	8	 Wilt thou even make void My judgment? Wilt thou condemn Me, that thou mayest be justified?
13874	18	40	9	 Or hast thou an arm like God? And canst thou thunder with a voice like Him?
13875	18	40	10	 Deck thyself now with majesty and excellency, and array thyself with glory and beauty.
13876	18	40	11	 Cast abroad the rage of thy wrath; and look upon every one that is proud, and abase him.
13877	18	40	12	 Look on every one that is proud, and bring him low; and tread down the wicked in their place.
13878	18	40	13	 Hide them in the dust together; bind their faces in the hidden place.
13879	18	40	14	 Then will I also confess unto thee that thine own right hand can save thee.
13880	18	40	15	 Behold now behemoth, which I made with thee; he eateth grass as an ox.
13881	18	40	16	 Lo now, his strength is in his loins, and his force is in the stays of his body.
13882	18	40	17	 He straineth his tail like a cedar; the sinews of his thighs are knit together.
13883	18	40	18	 His bones are as pipes of brass; his gristles are like bars of iron.
13884	18	40	19	 He is the beginning of the ways of God; He only that made him can make His sword to approach unto him.
13885	18	40	20	 Surely the mountains bring him forth food, and all the beasts of the field play there.
13886	18	40	21	 He lieth under the lotus-trees, in the covert of the reed, and fens.
13887	18	40	22	 The lotus-trees cover him with their shadow; the willows of the brook compass him about.
13888	18	40	23	 Behold, if a river overflow, he trembleth not; he is confident, though the Jordan rush forth to his mouth.
13889	18	40	24	 Shall any take him by his eyes, or pierce through his nose with a snare?
13890	18	41	1	 (40:25) Canst thou draw out leviathan with a fish-hook? or press down his tongue with a cord?
13891	18	41	2	 (40:26) Canst thou put a ring into his nose? or bore his jaw through with a hook?

13893	18	41	4	 (40:28) Will he make a covenant with thee, that thou shouldest take him for a servant for ever?
13894	18	41	5	 (40:29) Wilt thou play with him as with a bird? Or wilt thou bind him for thy maidens?

13897	18	41	8	 (40:32) Lay thy hand upon him; think upon the battle, thou wilt do so no more.
13898	18	41	9	 (41:1) Behold, the hope of him is in vain; shall not one be cast down even at the sight of him?
13899	18	41	10	 (41:2) None is so fierce that dare stir him up; who then is able to stand before Me?
13900	18	41	11	 (41:3) Who hath given Me anything beforehand, that I should repay him? Whatsoever is under the whole heaven is Mine.
13901	18	41	12	 (41:4) Would I keep silence concerning his boastings, or his proud talk, or his fair array of words?
13902	18	41	13	 (41:5) Who can uncover the face of his garment? Who shall come within his double bridle?
13903	18	41	14	 (41:6) Who can open the doors of his face? Round about his teeth is terror.
13904	18	41	15	 (41:7) His scales are his pride, shut up together as with a close seal.
13905	18	41	16	 (41:8) One is so near to another, that no air can come between them.
13906	18	41	17	 (41:9) They are joined one to another; they stick together, that they cannot be sundered.
13907	18	41	18	 (41:10) His sneezings flash forth light, and his eyes are like the eyelids of the morning.
13908	18	41	19	 (41:11) Out of his mouth go burning torches, and sparks of fire leap forth.
13909	18	41	20	 (41:12) Out of his nostrils goeth smoke, as out of a seething pot and burning rushes.
13910	18	41	21	 (41:13) His breath kindleth coals, and a flame goeth out of his mouth.
13911	18	41	22	 (41:14) In his neck abideth strength, and dismay danceth before him.
13912	18	41	23	 (41:15) The flakes of his flesh are joined together; they are firm upon him; they cannot be moved.
13913	18	41	24	 (41:16) His heart is as firm as a stone; yea, firm as the nether millstone.
13914	18	41	25	 (41:17) When he raiseth himself up, the mighty are afraid; by reason of despair they are beside themselves.
13915	18	41	26	 (41:18) If one lay at him with the sword, it will not hold; nor the spear, the dart, nor the pointed shaft.
13916	18	41	27	 (41:19) He esteemeth iron as straw, and brass as rotten wood.
13917	18	41	28	 (41:20) The arrow cannot make him flee; slingstones are turned with him into stubble.
13918	18	41	29	 (41:21) Clubs are accounted as stubble; he laugheth at the rattling of the javelin.
13919	18	41	30	 (41:22) Sharpest potsherds are under him; he spreadeth a threshing-sledge upon the mire.
13920	18	41	31	 (41:23) He maketh the deep to boil like a pot; he maketh the sea like a seething mixture.
13921	18	41	32	 (41:24) He maketh a path to shine after him; one would think the deep to be hoary.
13922	18	41	33	 (41:25) Upon earth there is not his like, who is made to be fearless.
13923	18	41	34	 (41:26) He looketh at all high things; he is king over all the proud beasts.
13924	18	42	1	 Then Job answered the LORD, and said:
13925	18	42	2	 I know that Thou canst do every thing, and that no purpose can be withholden from Thee.
13926	18	42	3	 Who is this that hideth counsel without knowledge? Therefore have I uttered that which I understood not, things too wonderful for me, which I knew not.
13927	18	42	4	 Hear, I beseech Thee, and I will speak; I will demand of Thee, and declare Thou unto me.
13928	18	42	5	 I had heard of Thee by the hearing of the ear; but now mine eye seeth Thee;
13929	18	42	6	 Wherefore I abhor my words, and repent, seeing I am dust and ashes.
13930	18	42	7	 And it was so, that after the LORD had spoken these words unto Job, the LORD said to Eliphaz the Temanite: 'My wrath is kindled against thee, and against thy two friends; for ye have not spoken of Me the thing that is right, as My servant Job hath.
13931	18	42	8	 Now therefore, take unto you seven bullocks and seven rams, and go to My servant Job, and offer up for yourselves a burnt-offering; and My servant Job shall pray for you; for him will I accept, that I do not unto you aught unseemly; for ye have not spoken of Me the thing that is right, as my servant Job hath.'
13932	18	42	9	 So Eliphaz the Temanite and Bildad the Shuhite and Zophar the Naamathite went, and did according as the LORD commanded them; and the LORD accepted Job.
13933	18	42	10	 And the LORD changed the fortune of Job, when he prayed for his friends; and the LORD gave Job twice as much as he had before.
13934	18	42	11	 Then came there unto him all his brethren, and all his sisters, and all they that had been of his acquaintance before, and did eat bread with him in his house; and they bemoaned him, and comforted him concerning all the evil that the LORD had brought upon him; every man also gave him a piece of money, and every one a ring of gold.
13935	18	42	12	 So the LORD blessed the latter end of Job more than his beginning; and he had fourteen thousand sheep, and six thousand camels, and a thousand yoke of oxen, and a thousand she-asses.
13936	18	42	13	 He had also seven sons and three daughters.
13937	18	42	14	 And he called the name of the first, Jemimah; and the name of the second, Keziah; and the name of the third, Keren-happuch.
13938	18	42	15	 And in all the land were no women found so fair as the daughters of Job; and their father gave them inheritance among their brethren.
13939	18	42	16	 And after this Job lived a hundred and forty years, and saw his sons, and his sons' sons, even four generations.
13940	18	42	17	 So Job died, being old and full of days.
13941	19	1	1	 HAPPY IS the man that hath not walked in the counsel of the wicked, nor stood in the way of sinners, nor sat in the seat of the scornful.
13942	19	1	2	 But his delight is in the law of the LORD; and in His law doth he meditate day and night.
13943	19	1	3	 And he shall be like a tree planted by streams of water, that bringeth forth its fruit in its season, and whose leaf doth not wither; and in whatsoever he doeth he shall prosper.
13944	19	1	4	 Not so the wicked; but they are like the chaff which the wind driveth away.
13945	19	1	5	 Therefore the wicked shall not stand in the judgment, nor sinners in the congregation of the righteous.
13946	19	1	6	 For the LORD regardeth the way of the righteous; but the way of the wicked shall perish.
13947	19	2	1	 Why are the nations in an uproar? And why do the peoples mutter in vain?
13948	19	2	2	 The kings of the earth stand up, and the rulers take counsel together, against the LORD, and against His anointed:
13949	19	2	3	 'Let us break their bands asunder, and cast away their cords from us.'
13950	19	2	4	 He that sitteth in heaven laugheth, the Lord hath them in derision.

13952	19	2	6	 'Truly it is I that have established My king upon Zion, My holy mountain.'
13953	19	2	7	 I will tell of the decree: the LORD said unto me: 'Thou art My son, this day have I begotten thee.
13954	19	2	8	 Ask of Me, and I will give the nations for thine inheritance, and the ends of the earth for thy possession.
13955	19	2	9	 Thou shalt break them with a rod of iron; thou shalt dash them in pieces like a potter's vessel.'
13956	19	2	10	 Now therefore, O ye kings, be wise; be admonished, ye judges of the earth.
13957	19	2	11	 Serve the LORD with fear, and rejoice with trembling.
13958	19	2	12	 Do homage in purity, lest He be angry, and ye perish in the way, when suddenly His wrath is kindled. Happy are all they that take refuge in Him.

14206	19	22	1	 (22:1) For the Leader; upon Aijeleth ha-Shahar. A Psalm of David. (22:2) My God, my God, why hast Thou forsaken me, and art far from my help at the words of my cry?
14207	19	22	2	 (22:3) O my God, I call by day, but Thou answerest not; and at night, and there is no surcease for me.
14208	19	22	3	 (22:4) Yet Thou art holy, O Thou that art enthroned upon the praises of Israel.
14209	19	22	4	 (22:5) In Thee did our fathers trust; they trusted, and Thou didst deliver them.
14210	19	22	5	 (22:6) Unto Thee they cried, and escaped; in Thee did they trust, and were not ashamed.
14211	19	22	6	 (22:7) But I am a worm, and no man; a reproach of men, and despised of the people.
14212	19	22	7	 (22:8) All they that see me laugh me to scorn; they shoot out the lip, they shake the head:
14213	19	22	8	 (22:9) 'Let him commit himself unto the LORD! let Him rescue him; let Him deliver him, seeing He delighteth in him.'
14214	19	22	9	 (22:10) For Thou art He that took me out of the womb; Thou madest me trust when I was upon my mother's breasts.
14215	19	22	10	 (22:11) Upon Thee I have been cast from my birth; Thou art my God from my mother's womb.
14216	19	22	11	 (22:12) Be not far from me; for trouble is near; for there is none to help.
14217	19	22	12	 (22:13) Many bulls have encompassed me; strong bulls of Bashan have beset me round.
14218	19	22	13	 (22:14) They open wide their mouth against me, as a ravening and a roaring lion.
14219	19	22	14	 (22:15) I am poured out like water, and all my bones are out of joint; my heart is become like wax; it is melted in mine inmost parts.
14220	19	22	15	 (22:16) My strength is dried up like a potsherd; and my tongue cleaveth to my throat; and Thou layest me in the dust of death.
14221	19	22	16	 (22:17) For dogs have encompassed me; a company of evil-doers have inclosed me; like a lion, they are at my hands and my feet.
14222	19	22	17	 (22:18) I may count all my bones; they look and gloat over me.
14223	19	22	18	 (22:19) They part my garments among them, and for my vesture do they cast lots.
14224	19	22	19	 (22:20) But Thou, O LORD, be not far off; O Thou my strength, hasten to help me.
14225	19	22	20	 (22:21) Deliver my soul from the sword; mine only one from the power of the dog.
14226	19	22	21	 (22:22) Save me from the lion's mouth; yea, from the horns of the wild-oxen do Thou answer me.
