17204	20	28	7	 A wise son observeth the teaching; but he that is a companion of gluttonous men shameth his father.
17205	20	28	8	 He that augmenteth his substance by interest and increase, gathereth it for him that is gracious to the poor.
17206	20	28	9	 He that turneth away his ear from hearing the law, even his prayer is an abomination.
17207	20	28	10	 Whoso causeth the upright to go astray in an evil way, he shall fall himself into his own pit; but the whole-hearted shall inherit good.
17208	20	28	11	 The rich man is wise in his own eyes; but the poor that hath understanding searcheth him through.
17209	20	28	12	 When the righteous exult, there is great glory; but when the wicked rise, men must be sought for.
17210	20	28	13	 He that covereth his transgressions shall not prosper; but whoso confesseth and forsaketh them shall obtain mercy.
17211	20	28	14	 Happy is the man that feareth alway; but he that hardeneth his heart shall fall into evil.
17212	20	28	15	 As a roaring lion, and a ravenous bear; so is a wicked ruler over a poor people.
17213	20	28	16	 The prince that lacketh understanding is also a great oppressor; but he that hateth covetousness shall prolong his days.
17214	20	28	17	 A man that is laden with the blood of any person shall hasten his steps unto the pit; none will support him.
17215	20	28	18	 Whoso walketh uprightly shall be saved; but he that is perverse in his ways shall fall at once.
17216	20	28	19	 He that tilleth his ground shall have plenty of bread; but he that followeth after vain things shall have poverty enough.
17217	20	28	20	 A faithful man shall abound with blessings; but he that maketh haste to be rich shall not be unpunished.
17218	20	28	21	 To have respect of persons is not good; for a man will transgress for a piece of bread.
17219	20	28	22	 He that hath an evil eye hasteneth after riches, and knoweth not that want shall come upon him.
17220	20	28	23	 He that rebuketh a man shall in the end find more favour than he that flattereth with the tongue.
17221	20	28	24	 Whoso robbeth his father or his mother, and saith: 'It is no transgression', the same is the companion of a destroyer.
17222	20	28	25	 He that is of a greedy spirit stirreth up strife; but he that putteth his trust in the LORD shall be abundantly gratified.
17223	20	28	26	 He that trusteth in his own heart is a fool; but whoso walketh wisely, he shall escape.
17224	20	28	27	 He that giveth unto the poor shall not lack; but he that hideth his eyes shall have many a curse.
17225	20	28	28	 When the wicked rise, men hide themselves; but when they perish, the righteous increase.
17226	20	29	1	 He that being often reproved hardeneth his neck shall suddenly be broken, and that without remedy.
17227	20	29	2	 When the righteous are increased, the people rejoice; but when the wicked beareth rule, the people sigh.
17228	20	29	3	 Whoso loveth wisdom rejoiceth his father; but he that keepeth company with harlots wasteth his substance.
17229	20	29	4	 The king by justice establisheth the land; but he that exacteth gifts overthroweth it.
17230	20	29	5	 A man that flattereth his neighbour spreadeth a net for his steps.
17231	20	29	6	 In the transgression of an evil man there is a snare; but the righteous doth sing and rejoice.
17232	20	29	7	 The righteous taketh knowledge of the cause of the poor; the wicked understandeth not knowledge.
17233	20	29	8	 Scornful men set a city in a blaze; but wise men turn away wrath.
17234	20	29	9	 If a wise man contendeth with a foolish man, whether he be angry or laugh, there will be no rest.
17235	20	29	10	 The men of blood hate him that is sincere; and as for the upright, they seek his life.
17236	20	29	11	 A fool spendeth all his spirit; but a wise man stilleth it within him.
17237	20	29	12	 If a ruler hearkeneth to falsehood, all his servants are wicked.
17238	20	29	13	 The poor man and the oppressor meet together; the LORD giveth light to the eyes of them both.
17239	20	29	14	 The king that faithfully judgeth the poor, his throne shall be established for ever.
17240	20	29	15	 The rod and reproof give wisdom; but a child left to himself causeth shame to his mother.
17241	20	29	16	 When the wicked are increased, transgression increaseth; but the righteous shall gaze upon their fall.
17242	20	29	17	 Correct thy son, and he will give thee rest; yea, he will give delight unto thy soul.
17243	20	29	18	 Where there is no vision, the people cast off restraint; but he that keepeth the law, happy is he.
17244	20	29	19	 A servant will not be corrected by words; for though he understand, there will be no response.
17245	20	29	20	 Seest thou a man that is hasty in his words? there is more hope for a fool than for him.
17246	20	29	21	 He that delicately bringeth up his servant from a child shall have him become master at the last.
17247	20	29	22	 An angry man stirreth up strife, and a wrathful man aboundeth in transgression.
17248	20	29	23	 A man's pride shall bring him low; but he that is of a lowly spirit shall attain to honour.
17249	20	29	24	 Whoso is partner with a thief hateth his own soul: he heareth the adjuration and uttereth nothing.
17250	20	29	25	 The fear of man bringeth a snare; but whoso putteth his trust in the LORD shall be set up on high.
17251	20	29	26	 Many seek the ruler's favour; but a man's judgment cometh from the LORD.
17252	20	29	27	 An unjust man is an abomination to the righteous; and he that is upright in the way is an abomination to the wicked.
17253	20	30	1	 The words of Agur the son of Jakeh; the burden. The man saith unto Ithiel, unto Ithiel and Ucal:
17254	20	30	2	 Surely I am brutish, unlike a man, and have not the understanding of a man;
17255	20	30	3	 And I have not learned wisdom, that I should have the knowledge of the Holy One.
17256	20	30	4	 Who hath ascended up into heaven, and descended? Who hath gathered the wind in his fists? Who hath bound the waters in his garment? Who hath established all the ends of the earth? What is his name, and what is his son's name, if thou knowest?
17257	20	30	5	 Every word of God is tried; He is a shield unto them that take refuge in Him.
17258	20	30	6	 Add thou not unto His words, lest He reprove thee, and thou be found a liar.
17259	20	30	7	 Two things have I asked of Thee; deny me them not before I die:
17260	20	30	8	 Remove far from me falsehood and lies; give me neither poverty nor riches; feed me with mine allotted bread;
17261	20	30	9	 Lest I be full, and deny, and say: 'Who is the LORD?' Or lest I be poor, and steal, and profane the name of my God.
17262	20	30	10	 Slander not a servant unto his master, lest he curse thee, and thou be found guilty.
17263	20	30	11	 There is a generation that curse their father, and do not bless their mother.
17264	20	30	12	 There is a generation that are pure in their own eyes, and yet are not washed from their filthiness.
17265	20	30	13	 There is a generation, Oh how lofty are their eyes! and their eyelids are lifted up.
17266	20	30	14	 There is a generation whose teeth are as swords, and their great teeth as knives, to devour the poor from off the earth, and the needy from among men.
17267	20	30	15	 The horseleech hath two daughters: 'Give, give.' There are three things that are never satisfied, yea, four that say not: 'Enough':
17268	20	30	16	 The grave; and the barren womb; the earth that is not satisfied with water; and the fire that saith not: 'Enough.'
17269	20	30	17	 The eye that mocketh at his father, and despiseth to obey his mother, the ravens of the valley shall pick it out, and the young vultures shall eat it.
17270	20	30	18	 There are three things which are too wonderful for me, yea, four which I know not:
17271	20	30	19	 The way of an eagle in the air; the way of a serpent upon a rock; the way of a ship in the midst of the sea; and the way of a man with a young woman.
17272	20	30	20	 So is the way of an adulterous woman; she eateth, and wipeth her mouth, and saith: 'I have done no wickedness.'
17273	20	30	21	 For three things the earth doth quake, and for four it cannot endure:
17274	20	30	22	 For a servant when he reigneth; and a churl when he is filled with food;
17275	20	30	23	 For an odious woman when she is married; and a handmaid that is heir to her mistress.
17276	20	30	24	 There are four things which are little upon the earth, but they are exceeding wise:
17277	20	30	25	 The ants are a people not strong, yet they provide their food in the summer;
17278	20	30	26	 The rock-badgers are but a feeble folk, yet make they their houses in the crags;
17279	20	30	27	 The locusts have no king, yet go they forth all of them by bands;
17280	20	30	28	 The spider thou canst take with the hands, yet is she in kings' palaces.
17281	20	30	29	 There are three things which are stately in their march, yea, four which are stately in going:
17282	20	30	30	 The lion, which is mightiest among beasts, and turneth not away for any;
17283	20	30	31	 The greyhound; the he-goat also; and the king, against whom there is no rising up.
17284	20	30	32	 If thou hast done foolishly in lifting up thyself, or if thou hast planned devices, lay thy hand upon thy mouth.
17285	20	30	33	 For the churning of milk bringeth forth curd, and the wringing of the nose bringeth forth blood; so the forcing of wrath bringeth forth strife.
17286	20	31	1	 The words of king Lemuel; the burden wherewith his mother corrected him.
17287	20	31	2	 What, my son? and what, O son of my womb? and what, O son of my vows?
17288	20	31	3	 Give not thy strength unto women, nor thy ways to that which destroyeth kings.
17289	20	31	4	 It is not for kings, O Lemuel, it is not for kings to drink wine: nor for princes to say: 'Where is strong drink?'
17290	20	31	5	 Lest they drink, and forget that which is decreed, and pervert the justice due to any that is afflicted.
17291	20	31	6	 Give strong drink unto him that is ready to perish, and wine unto the bitter in soul;
17292	20	31	7	 Let him drink, and forget his poverty, and remember his misery no more.
17293	20	31	8	 Open thy mouth for the dumb, in the cause of all such as are appointed to destruction.
17294	20	31	9	 Open thy mouth, judge righteously, and plead the cause of the poor and needy.
17295	20	31	10	 A woman of valour who can find? for her price is far above rubies.
17296	20	31	11	 The heart of her husband doth safely trust in her, and he hath no lack of gain.
17297	20	31	12	 She doeth him good and not evil all the days of her life.
17298	20	31	13	 She seeketh wool and flax, and worketh willingly with her hands.
17299	20	31	14	 She is like the merchant-ships; she bringeth her food from afar.
17300	20	31	15	 She riseth also while it is yet night, and giveth food to her household, and a portion to her maidens.
17301	20	31	16	 She considereth a field, and buyeth it; with the fruit of her hands she planteth a vineyard.
17302	20	31	17	 She girdeth her loins with strength, and maketh strong her arms.
17303	20	31	18	 She perceiveth that her merchandise is good; her lamp goeth not out by night.
17304	20	31	19	 She layeth her hands to the distaff, and her hands hold the spindle.
17305	20	31	20	 She stretcheth out her hand to the poor; yea, she reacheth forth her hands to the needy.
17306	20	31	21	 She is not afraid of the snow for her household; for all her household are clothed with scarlet.
17307	20	31	22	 She maketh for herself coverlets; her clothing is fine linen and purple.
17308	20	31	23	 Her husband is known in the gates, when he sitteth among the elders of the land.
17309	20	31	24	 She maketh linen garments and selleth them; and delivereth girdles unto the merchant.
17310	20	31	25	 Strength and dignity are her clothing; and she laugheth at the time to come.
17311	20	31	26	 She openeth her mouth with wisdom; and the law of kindness is on her tongue.
17312	20	31	27	 She looketh well to the ways of her household, and eateth not the bread of idleness.
17313	20	31	28	 Her children rise up, and call her blessed; her husband also, and he praiseth her:
17314	20	31	29	 'Many daughters have done valiantly, but thou excellest them all.'
17315	20	31	30	 Grace is deceitful, and beauty is vain; but a woman that feareth the LORD, she shall be praised.
17316	20	31	31	 Give her of the fruit of her hands; and let her works praise her in the gates.
17317	21	1	1	 THE WORDS OF the Koheleth, the son of David, king in Jerusalem.
17318	21	1	2	 Vanity of vanities, saith Koheleth; vanity of vanities, all is vanity.
17319	21	1	3	 What profit hath man of all his labour wherein he laboureth under the sun?
17320	21	1	4	 One generation passeth away, and another generation cometh; and the earth abideth for ever.
17321	21	1	5	 The sun also ariseth, and the sun goeth down, and hasteth to his place where he ariseth.
17322	21	1	6	 The wind goeth toward the south, and turneth about unto the north; it turneth about continually in its circuit, and the wind returneth again to its circuits.
17323	21	1	7	 All the rivers run into the sea, yet the sea is not full; unto the place whither the rivers go, thither they go again.
17324	21	1	8	 All things toil to weariness; man cannot utter it, the eye is not satisfied with seeing, nor the ear filled with hearing.
17325	21	1	9	 That which hath been is that which shall be, and that which hath been done is that which shall be done; and there is nothing new under the sun.
17326	21	1	10	 Is there a thing whereof it is said: 'See, this is new'? --it hath been already, in the ages which were before us.
17327	21	1	11	 There is no remembrance of them of former times; neither shall there be any remembrance of them of latter times that are to come, among those that shall come after.
17328	21	1	12	 I Koheleth have been king over Israel in Jerusalem.
17329	21	1	13	 And I applied my heart to seek and to search out by wisdom concerning all things that are done under heaven; it is a sore task that God hath given to the sons of men to be exercised therewith.
17330	21	1	14	 I have seen all the works that are done under the sun; and, behold, all is vanity and a striving after wind.
17331	21	1	15	 That which is crooked cannot be made straight; and that which is wanting cannot be numbered.
17332	21	1	16	 I spoke with my own heart, saying: 'Lo, I have gotten great wisdom, more also than all that were before me over Jerusalem'; yea, my heart hath had great experience of wisdom and knowledge.
17333	21	1	17	 And I applied my heart to know wisdom, and to know madness and folly--I perceived that this also was a striving after wind.
17334	21	1	18	 For in much wisdom is much vexation; and he that increaseth knowledge increaseth sorrow.
17335	21	2	1	 I said in my heart: 'Come now, I will try thee with mirth, and enjoy pleasure'; and, behold, this also was vanity.
17336	21	2	2	 I said of laughter: 'It is mad'; and of mirth: 'What doth it accomplish?'
17337	21	2	3	 I searched in my heart how to pamper my flesh with wine, and, my heart conducting itself with wisdom, how yet to lay hold on folly, till I might see which it was best for the sons of men that they should do under the heaven the few days of their life.
17338	21	2	4	 I made me great works; I builded me houses; I planted me vineyards;
17339	21	2	5	 I made me gardens and parks, and I planted trees in them of all kinds of fruit;
17340	21	2	6	 I made me pools of water, to water therefrom the wood springing up with trees;
17341	21	2	7	 I acquired men-servants and maid-servants, and had servants born in my house; also I had great possessions of herds and flocks, above all that were before me in Jerusalem;
17342	21	2	8	 I gathered me also silver and gold, and treasure such as kings and the provinces have as their own; I got me men-singers and women-singers, and the delights of the sons of men, women very many.
17343	21	2	9	 So I was great, and increased more than all that were before me in Jerusalem; also my wisdom stood me in stead.
17344	21	2	10	 And whatsoever mine eyes desired I kept not from them; I withheld not my heart from any joy, for my heart had joy of all my labour; and this was my portion from all my labour.
17345	21	2	11	 Then I looked on all the works that my hands had wrought, and on the labour that I had laboured to do; and, behold, all was vanity and a striving after wind, and there was no profit under the sun.
17346	21	2	12	 And I turned myself to behold wisdom, and madness and folly; for what can the man do that cometh after the king? even that which hath been already done.
17347	21	2	13	 Then I saw that wisdom excelleth folly, as far as light excelleth darkness.
17348	21	2	14	 The wise man, his eyes are in his head; but the fool walketh in darkness. And I also perceived that one event happeneth to them all.
17349	21	2	15	 Then said I in my heart: 'As it happeneth to the fool, so will it happen even to me; and why was I then more wise?' Then I said in my heart, that this also is vanity.
17350	21	2	16	 For of the wise man, even as of the fool, there is no remembrance for ever; seeing that in the days to come all will long ago have been forgotten. And how must the wise man die even as the fool!
17351	21	2	17	 So I hated life; because the work that is wrought under the sun was grievous unto me; for all is vanity and a striving after wind.
17352	21	2	18	 And I hated all my labour wherein I laboured under the sun, seeing that I must leave it unto the man that shall be after me.
17353	21	2	19	 And who knoweth whether he will be a wise man or a fool? yet will he have rule over all my labour wherein I have laboured, and wherein I have shown myself wise under the sun. This also is vanity.
17354	21	2	20	 Therefore I turned about to cause my heart to despair concerning all the labour wherein I had laboured under the sun.
17355	21	2	21	 For there is a man whose labour is with wisdom, and with knowledge, and with skill; yet to a man that hath not laboured therein shall he leave it for his portion. This also is vanity and a great evil.
17356	21	2	22	 For what hath a man of all his labour, and of the striving of his heart, wherein he laboureth under the sun?
17357	21	2	23	 For all his days are pains, and his occupation vexation; yea, even in the night his heart taketh not rest. This also is vanity.
17358	21	2	24	 There is nothing better for a man than that he should eat and drink, and make his soul enjoy pleasure for his labour. This also I saw, that it is from the hand of God.
17359	21	2	25	 For who will eat, or who will enjoy, if not I?
17360	21	2	26	 For to the man that is good in His sight He giveth wisdom, and knowledge, and joy; but to the sinner He giveth the task, to gather and to heap up, that he may leave to him that is good in the sight of God. This also is vanity and a striving after wind.
17361	21	3	1	 To every thing there is a season, and a time to every purpose under the heaven:
17362	21	3	2	 A time to be born, and a time to die; a time to plant, and a time to pluck up that which is planted;
17363	21	3	3	 A time to kill, and a time to heal; a time to break down, and a time to build up;
17364	21	3	4	 A time to weep, and a time to laugh; a time to mourn, and a time to dance;
17365	21	3	5	 A time to cast away stones, and a time to gather stones together; a time to embrace, and a time to refrain from embracing;
17366	21	3	6	 A time to seek, and a time to lose; a time to keep, and a time to cast away;
17367	21	3	7	 A time to rend, and a time to sew; a time to keep silence, and a time to speak;
17368	21	3	8	 A time to love, and a time to hate; a time for war, and a time for peace.
17369	21	3	9	 What profit hath he that worketh in that he laboureth?
17370	21	3	10	 I have seen the task which God hath given to the sons of men to be exercised therewith.
17371	21	3	11	 He hath made every thing beautiful in its time; also He hath set the world in their heart, yet so that man cannot find out the work that God hath done from the beginning even to the end.
17372	21	3	12	 I know that there is nothing better for them, than to rejoice, and to get pleasure so long as they live.
17373	21	3	13	 But also that every man should eat and drink, and enjoy pleasure for all his labour, is the gift of God.
17374	21	3	14	 I know that, whatsoever God doeth, it shall be for ever; nothing can be added to it, nor any thing taken from it; and God hath so made it, that men should fear before Him.
17375	21	3	15	 That which is hath been long ago, and that which is to be hath already been; and God seeketh that which is pursued.
17376	21	3	16	 And moreover I saw under the sun, in the place of justice, that wickedness was there; and in the place of righteousness, that wickedness was there.
17377	21	3	17	 I said in my heart: 'The righteous and the wicked God will judge; for there is a time there for every purpose and for every work.'
17378	21	3	18	 I said in my heart: 'It is because of the sons of men, that God may sift them, and that they may see that they themselves are but as beasts.'
17379	21	3	19	 For that which befalleth the sons of men befalleth beasts; even one thing befalleth them; as the one dieth, so dieth the other; yea, they have all one breath; so that man hath no pre-eminence above a beast; for all is vanity.
17380	21	3	20	 All go unto one place; all are of the dust, and all return to dust.
17381	21	3	21	 Who knoweth the spirit of man whether it goeth upward, and the spirit of the beast whether it goeth downward to the earth?
17382	21	3	22	 Wherefore I perceived that there is nothing better, than that a man should rejoice in his works; for that is his portion; for who shall bring him to see what shall be after him?
17383	21	4	1	 But I returned and considered all the oppressions that are done under the sun; and behold the tears of such as were oppressed, and they had no comforter; and on the side of their oppressors there was power, but they had no comforter.
17384	21	4	2	 Wherefore I praised the dead that are already dead more than the living that are yet alive;
17385	21	4	3	 but better than they both is he that hath not yet been, who hath not seen the evil work that is done under the sun.
17386	21	4	4	 Again, I considered all labour and all excelling in work, that it is a man's rivalry with his neighbour. This also is vanity and a striving after wind.
17387	21	4	5	 The fool foldeth his hands together, and eateth his own flesh.
17388	21	4	6	 Better is a handful of quietness, than both the hands full of labour and striving after wind.
17389	21	4	7	 Then I returned and saw vanity under the sun.
17390	21	4	8	 There is one that is alone, and he hath not a second; yea, he hath neither son nor brother; yet is there no end of all his labour, neither is his eye satisfied with riches: 'for whom then do I labour, and bereave my soul of pleasure?' This also is vanity, yea, it is a grievous business.
17391	21	4	9	 Two are better than one; because they have a good reward for their labour.
17392	21	4	10	 For if they fall, the one will lift up his fellow; but woe to him that is alone when he falleth, and hath not another to lift him up.
17393	21	4	11	 Again, if two lie together, then they have warmth; but how can one be warm alone?
17394	21	4	12	 And if a man prevail against him that is alone, two shall withstand him; and a threefold cord is not quickly broken.
17395	21	4	13	 Better is a poor and wise child than an old and foolish king, who knoweth not how to receive admonition any more.
17396	21	4	14	 For out of prison he came forth to be king; although in his kingdom he was born poor.
17397	21	4	15	 I saw all the living that walk under the sun, that they were with the child, the second, that was to stand up in his stead.
17398	21	4	16	 There was no end of all the people, even of all them whom he did lead; yet they that come after shall not rejoice in him. Surely this also is vanity and a striving after wind.
17399	21	5	1	 (4:17) Guard thy foot when thou goest to the house of God, and be ready to hearken: it is better than when fools give sacrifices; for they know not that they do evil.
17400	21	5	2	 (5:1) Be not rash with thy mouth, and let not thy heart be hasty to utter a word before God; for God is in heaven, and thou upon earth; therefore let thy words be few.
17401	21	5	3	 (5:2) For a dream cometh through a multitude of business; and a fool's voice through a multitude of words.
17402	21	5	4	 (5:3) When thou vowest a vow unto God, defer not to pay it; for He hath no pleasure in fools; pay that which thou vowest.
17403	21	5	5	 (5:4) Better is it that thou shouldest not vow, than that thou shouldest vow and not pay.
17404	21	5	6	 (5:5) Suffer not thy mouth to bring thy flesh into guilt, neither say thou before the messenger, that it was an error; wherefore should God be angry at thy voice, and destroy the work of thy hands?
17405	21	5	7	 (5:6) For through the multitude of dreams and vanities there are also many words; but fear thou God.
17406	21	5	8	 (5:7) If thou seest the oppression of the poor, and the violent perverting of justice and righteousness in the state, marvel not at the matter; for one higher than the high watcheth, and there are higher than they.
17407	21	5	9	 (5:8) But the profit of a land every way is a king that maketh himself servant to the field.
17408	21	5	10	 (5:9) He that loveth silver shall not be satisfied with silver; nor he that loveth abundance, with increase; this also is vanity.
17409	21	5	11	 (5:10) When goods increase, they are increased that eat them; and what advantage is there to the owner thereof, saving the beholding of them with his eyes?
17410	21	5	12	 (5:11) Sweet is the sleep of a labouring man, whether he eat little or much; but the satiety of the rich will not suffer him to sleep.
17411	21	5	13	 (5:12) There is a grievous evil which I have seen under the sun, namely, riches kept by the owner thereof to his hurt;
17412	21	5	14	 (5:13) and those riches perish by evil adventure; and if he hath begotten a son, there is nothing in his hand.
17413	21	5	15	 (5:14) As he came forth of his mother's womb, naked shall he go back as he came, and shall take nothing for his labour, which he may carry away in his hand.
17414	21	5	16	 (5:15) And this also is a grievous evil, that in all points as he came, so shall he go; and what profit hath he that he laboureth for the wind?
17415	21	5	17	 (5:16) All his days also he eateth in darkness, and he hath much vexation and sickness and wrath.
17416	21	5	18	 (5:17) Behold that which I have seen: it is good, yea, it is comely for one to eat and to drink, and to enjoy pleasure for all his labour, wherein he laboureth under the sun, all the days of his life which God hath given him; for this is his portion.
17417	21	5	19	 (5:18) Every man also to whom God hath given riches and wealth, and hath given him power to eat thereof, and to take his portion, and to rejoice in his labour--this is the gift of God.
17418	21	5	20	 (5:19) For let him remember the days of his life that they are not many; for God answereth him in the joy of his heart.
17419	21	6	1	 There is an evil which I have seen under the sun, and it is heavy upon men:
17420	21	6	2	 a man to whom God giveth riches, wealth, and honour, so that he wanteth nothing for his soul of all that he desireth, yet God giveth him not power to eat thereof, but a stranger eateth it; this is vanity, and it is an evil disease.
17421	21	6	3	 If a man beget a hundred children, and live many years, so that the days of his years are many, but his soul have not enough of good, and moreover he have no burial; I say, that an untimely birth is better than he;
17422	21	6	4	 for it cometh in vanity, and departeth in darkness, and the name thereof is covered with darkness;
17423	21	6	5	 moreover it hath not seen the sun nor known it; this hath gratification rather than the other;
17424	21	6	6	 yea, though he live a thousand years twice told, and enjoy no good; do not all go to one place?
17425	21	6	7	 All the labour of man is for his mouth, and yet the appetite is not filled.
17426	21	6	8	 For what advantage hath the wise more than the fool? or the poor man that hath understanding, in walking before the living?
17427	21	6	9	 Better is the seeing of the eyes than the wandering of the desire; this also is vanity and a striving after wind.
17428	21	6	10	 Whatsoever cometh into being, the name thereof was given long ago, and it is foreknown what man is; neither can he contend with Him that is mightier than he.
17429	21	6	11	 Seeing there are many words that increase vanity, what is man the better?
17430	21	6	12	 For who knoweth what is good for man in his life, all the days of his vain life which he spendeth as a shadow? for who can tell a man what shall be after him under the sun?
17431	21	7	1	 A good name is better than precious oil; and the day of death than the day of one's birth.
17432	21	7	2	 It is better to go to the house of mourning, than to go to the house of feasting; for that is the end of all men, and the living will lay it to his heart.
17433	21	7	3	 Vexation is better than laughter; for by the sadness of the countenance the heart may be gladdened.
17434	21	7	4	 The heart of the wise is in the house of mourning; but the heart of fools is in the house of mirth.
17435	21	7	5	 It is better to hear the rebuke of the wise, than for a man to hear the song of fools.
17436	21	7	6	 For as the crackling of thorns under a pot, so is the laughter of the fool; this also is vanity.
17437	21	7	7	 Surely oppression turneth a wise man into a fool; and a gift destroyeth the understanding.
17438	21	7	8	 Better is the end of a thing than the beginning thereof; and the patient in spirit is better than the proud in spirit.
17439	21	7	9	 Be not hasty in thy spirit to be angry; for anger resteth in the bosom of fools.
17440	21	7	10	 Say not thou: 'How was it that the former days were better than these?' for it is not out of wisdom that thou inquirest concerning this.
17441	21	7	11	 Wisdom is good with an inheritance, yea, a profit to them that see the sun.
17442	21	7	12	 For wisdom is a defence, even as money is a defence; but the excellency of knowledge is, that wisdom preserveth the life of him that hath it.
17443	21	7	13	 Consider the work of God; for who can make that straight, which He hath made crooked?
17444	21	7	14	 In the day of prosperity be joyful, and in the day of adversity consider; God hath made even the one as well as the other, to the end that man should find nothing after him.
17445	21	7	15	 All things have I seen in the days of my vanity; there is a righteous man that perisheth in his righteousness, and there is a wicked man that prolongeth his life in his evil-doing.
17446	21	7	16	 Be not righteous overmuch; neither make thyself overwise; why shouldest thou destroy thyself?
17447	21	7	17	 Be not overmuch wicked, neither be thou foolish; why shouldest thou die before thy time?
17448	21	7	18	 It is good that thou shouldest take hold of the one; yea, also from the other withdraw not thy hand; for he that feareth God shall discharge himself of them all.
17449	21	7	19	 Wisdom is a stronghold to the wise man more than ten rulers that are in a city.
17450	21	7	20	 For there is not a righteous man upon earth, that doeth good, and sinneth not.
17451	21	7	21	 Also take not heed unto all words that are spoken, lest thou hear thy servant curse thee;
17452	21	7	22	 for oftentimes also thine own heart knoweth that thou thyself likewise hast cursed others.
17453	21	7	23	 All this have I tried by wisdom; I said: 'I will get wisdom'; but it was far from me.
17454	21	7	24	 That which is is far off, and exceeding deep; who can find it out?
17455	21	7	25	 I turned about, and applied my heart to know and to search out, and to seek wisdom and the reason of things, and to know wickedness to be folly, and foolishness to be madness;
17456	21	7	26	 and I find more bitter than death the woman, whose heart is snares and nets, and her hands as bands; whoso pleaseth God shall escape from her; but the sinner shall be taken by her.
17457	21	7	27	 Behold, this have I found, saith Koheleth, adding one thing to another, to find out the account;
17458	21	7	28	 which yet my soul sought, but I found not; one man among a thousand have I found; but a woman among all those have I not found.
17459	21	7	29	 Behold, this only have I found, that God made man upright; but they have sought out many inventions.
17460	21	8	1	 Who is as the wise man? and who knoweth the interpretation of a thing? A man's wisdom maketh his face to shine, and the boldness of his face is changed.
17461	21	8	2	 I counsel thee: keep the king's command, and that in regard of the oath of God.
17462	21	8	3	 Be not hasty to go out of his presence; stand not in an evil thing; for he doeth whatsoever pleaseth him.
17463	21	8	4	 Forasmuch as the king's word hath power; and who may say unto him: 'What doest thou?'
17464	21	8	5	 Whoso keepeth the commandment shall know no evil thing; and a wise man's heart discerneth time and judgment.
17465	21	8	6	 For to every matter there is a time and judgment; for the evil of man is great upon him.
17466	21	8	7	 For he knoweth not that which shall be; for even when it cometh to pass, who shall declare it unto him?
17467	21	8	8	 There is no man that hath power over the wind to retain the wind; neither hath he power over the day of death; and there is no discharge in war; neither shall wickedness deliver him that is given to it.
17468	21	8	9	 All this have I seen, even applied my heart thereto, whatever the work that is done under the sun; what time one man had power over another to his hurt.
17469	21	8	10	 And so I saw the wicked buried, and they entered into their rest; but they that had done right went away from the holy place, and were forgotten in the city; this also is vanity.
17470	21	8	11	 Because sentence against an evil work is not executed speedily, therefore the heart of the sons of men is fully set in them to do evil;
17471	21	8	12	 because a sinner doeth evil a hundred times, and prolongeth his days--though yet I know that it shall be well with them that fear God, that fear before Him;
17472	21	8	13	 but it shall not be well with the wicked, neither shall he prolong his days, which are as a shadow, because he feareth not before God.
17473	21	8	14	 There is a vanity which is done upon the earth: that there are righteous men, unto whom it happeneth according to the work of the wicked; again, there are wicked men, to whom it happeneth according to the work of the righteous--I said that this also is vanity.
17474	21	8	15	 So I commended mirth, that a man hath no better thing under the sun, than to eat, and to drink, and to be merry, and that this should accompany him in his labour all the days of his life which God hath given him under the sun.
17475	21	8	16	 When I applied my heart to know wisdom, and to see the business that is done upon the earth--for neither day nor night do men see sleep with their eyes--
17476	21	8	17	 then I beheld all the work of God, that man cannot find out the work that is done under the sun; because though a man labour to seek it out, yet he shall not find it; yea further, though a wise man think to know it, yet shall he not be able to find it.
17477	21	9	1	 For all this I laid to my heart, even to make clear all this: that the righteous, and the wise, and their works, are in the hand of God; whether it be love or hatred, man knoweth it not; all is before them.
17478	21	9	2	 All things come alike to all; there is one event to the righteous and to the wicked; to the good and to the clean and to the unclean; to him that sacrificeth and to him that sacrificeth not; as is the good, so is the sinner, and he that sweareth, as he that feareth an oath.
17479	21	9	3	 This is an evil in all that is done under the sun, that there is one event unto all; yea also, the heart of the sons of men is full of evil, and madness is in their heart while they live, and after that they go to the dead.
17480	21	9	4	 For to him that is joined to all the living there is hope; for a living dog is better than a dead lion.
17481	21	9	5	 For the living know that they shall die; but the dead know not any thing, neither have they any more a reward; for the memory of them is forgotten.
17482	21	9	6	 As well their love, as their hatred and their envy, is long ago perished; neither have they any more a portion for ever in any thing that is done under the sun.
17483	21	9	7	 Go thy way, eat thy bread with joy, and drink thy wine with a merry heart; for God hath already accepted thy works.
17484	21	9	8	 Let thy garments be always white; and let thy head lack no oil.
17485	21	9	9	 Enjoy life with the wife whom thou lovest all the days of the life of thy vanity, which He hath given thee under the sun, all the days of thy vanity; for that is thy portion in life, and in thy labour wherein thou labourest under the sun.
17486	21	9	10	 Whatsoever thy hand attaineth to do by thy strength, that do; for there is no work, nor device, nor knowledge, nor wisdom, in the grave, whither thou goest.
17487	21	9	11	 I returned, and saw under the sun, that the race is not to the swift, nor the battle to the strong, neither yet bread to the wise, nor yet riches to men of understanding, nor yet favour to men of skill; but time and chance happeneth to them all.
17488	21	9	12	 For man also knoweth not his time; as the fishes that are taken in an evil net, and as the birds that are caught in the snare, even so are the sons of men snared in an evil time, when it falleth suddenly upon them.
17489	21	9	13	 This also have I seen as wisdom under the sun, and it seemed great unto me:
17490	21	9	14	 there was a little city, and few men within it; and there came a great king against it, and besieged it, and built great bulwarks against it;
17491	21	9	15	 now there was found in it a man poor and wise, and he by his wisdom delivered the city; yet no man remembered that same poor man.
17492	21	9	16	 Then said I: 'Wisdom is better than strength; nevertheless the poor man's wisdom is despised, and his words are not heard.'
17493	21	9	17	 The words of the wise spoken in quiet are more acceptable than the cry of a ruler among fools.
17494	21	9	18	 Wisdom is better than weapons of war; but one sinner destroyeth much good.
17495	21	10	1	 Dead flies make the ointment of the perfumer fetid and putrid; so doth a little folly outweigh wisdom and honour.
17496	21	10	2	 A wise man's understanding is at his right hand; but a fool's understanding at his left.
17497	21	10	3	 Yea also, when a fool walketh by the way, his understanding faileth him, and he saith to every one that he is a fool.
17498	21	10	4	 If the spirit of the ruler rise up against thee, leave not thy place; for gentleness allayeth great offences.
17499	21	10	5	 There is an evil which I have seen under the sun, like an error which proceedeth from a ruler:
17500	21	10	6	 Folly is set on great heights, and the rich sit in low place.
17501	21	10	7	 I have seen servants upon horses, and princes walking as servants upon the earth.
17502	21	10	8	 He that diggeth a pit shall fall into it; and whoso breaketh through a fence, a serpent shall bite him.
17503	21	10	9	 Whoso quarrieth stones shall be hurt therewith; and he that cleaveth wood is endangered thereby.
17504	21	10	10	 If the iron be blunt, and one do not whet the edge, then must he put to more strength; but wisdom is profitable to direct.
17505	21	10	11	 If the serpent bite before it is charmed, then the charmer hath no advantage.
17506	21	10	12	 The words of a wise man's mouth are gracious; but the lips of a fool will swallow up himself.
17507	21	10	13	 The beginning of the words of his mouth is foolishness; and the end of his talk is grievous madness.
17508	21	10	14	 A fool also multiplieth words; yet man knoweth not what shall be; and that which shall be after him, who can tell him?
17509	21	10	15	 The labour of fools wearieth every one of them, for he knoweth not how to go to the city.
17510	21	10	16	 Woe to thee, O land, when thy king is a boy, and thy princes feast in the morning!
17511	21	10	17	 Happy art thou, O land, when thy king is a free man, and thy princes eat in due season, in strength, and not in drunkenness!
17512	21	10	18	 By slothfulness the rafters sink in; and through idleness of the hands the house leaketh.
17513	21	10	19	 A feast is made for laughter, and wine maketh glad the life; and money answereth all things.
17514	21	10	20	 Curse not the king, no, not in thy thought, and curse not the rich in thy bedchamber; for a bird of the air shall carry the voice, and that which hath wings shall tell the matter.
17515	21	11	1	 Cast thy bread upon the waters, for thou shalt find it after many days.
17516	21	11	2	 Divide a portion into seven, yea, even into eight; for thou knowest not what evil shall be upon the earth.
17517	21	11	3	 If the clouds be full of rain, they empty themselves upon the earth; and if a tree fall in the south, or in the north, in the place where the tree falleth, there shall it be.
17518	21	11	4	 He that observeth the wind shall not sow; and he that regardeth the clouds shall not reap.
17519	21	11	5	 As thou knowest not what is the way of the wind, nor how the bones do grow in the womb of her that is with child; even so thou knowest not the work of God who doeth all things.
17520	21	11	6	 In the morning sow thy seed, and in the evening withhold not thy hand; for thou knowest not which shall prosper, whether this or that, or whether they both shall be alike good.
17521	21	11	7	 And the light is sweet, and a pleasant thing it is for the eyes to behold the sun.
17522	21	11	8	 For if a man live many years, let him rejoice in them all, and remember the days of darkness, for they shall be many. all that cometh is vanity.
17523	21	11	9	 Rejoice, O young man, in thy youth; and let thy heart cheer thee in the days of thy youth, and walk in the ways of thy heart, and in the sight of thine eyes; but know thou, that for all these things God will bring thee into judgment.
17524	21	11	10	 Therefore remove vexation from thy heart, and put away evil from thy flesh; for childhood and youth are vanity.
17525	21	12	1	 Remember then thy Creator in the days of thy youth, before the evil days come, and the years draw nigh, when thou shalt say: 'I have no pleasure in them';
17526	21	12	2	 Before the sun, and the light, and the moon, and the stars, are darkened, and the clouds return after the rain;
17527	21	12	3	 In the day when the keepers of the house shall tremble, and the strong men shall bow themselves, and the grinders cease because they are few, and those that look out shall be darkened in the windows,
17528	21	12	4	 And the doors shall be shut in the street, when the sound of the grinding is low; and one shall start up at the voice of a bird, and all the daughters of music shall be brought low;
17529	21	12	5	 Also when they shall be afraid of that which is high, and terrors shall be in the way; and the almond-tree shall blossom, and the grasshopper shall drag itself along, and the caperberry shall fail; because man goeth to his long home, and the mourners go about the streets;
17530	21	12	6	 Before the silver cord is snapped asunder, and the golden bowl is shattered, and the pitcher is broken at the fountain, and the wheel falleth shattered, into the pit;
17531	21	12	7	 And the dust returneth to the earth as it was, and the spirit returneth unto God who gave it.
17532	21	12	8	 Vanity of vanities, saith Koheleth; all is vanity.
17533	21	12	9	 And besides that Koheleth was wise, he also taught the people knowledge; yea, he pondered, and sought out, and set in order many proverbs.
17534	21	12	10	 Koheleth sought to find out words of delight, and that which was written uprightly, even words of truth.
17535	21	12	11	 The words of the wise are as goads, and as nails well fastened are those that are composed in collections; they are given from one shepherd.
17536	21	12	12	 And furthermore, my son, be admonished: of making many books there is no end; and much study is a weariness of the flesh.
17537	21	12	13	 The end of the matter, all having been heard: fear God, and keep His commandments; for this is the whole man.
17538	21	12	14	 For God shall bring every work into the judgment concerning every hidden thing, whether it be good or whether it be evil.
17539	22	1	1	 THE SONG of songs, which is Solomon's.

17542	22	1	4	 Draw me, we will run after thee; the king hath brought me into his chambers; we will be glad and rejoice in thee, we will find thy love more fragrant than wine! sincerely do they love thee.
